summary: Elon Musk and Tesla are being sued for $258 billion by a Dogecoin investor who alleges they ran a pyramid scheme to inflate the cryptocurrency's value. The plaintiff, Keith Johnson, claims Musk manipulated Dogecoin for "profit, exposure and amusement" despite knowing it had no intrinsic value, and seeks damages for the $86 billion decline in Dogecoin's market value since May 2021. Johnson also wants to prevent Musk and his companies from promoting Dogecoin and to have it declared gambling under federal and New York law.

title: Tesla prices rise by thousands, again: Model Y now starts at $67,190
summary: Tesla has once again raised prices for several of its models in the U.S. market, with hikes ranging from $2,000 to $6,000. The Model Y's base price increased by $3,000 to $67,190, while the Model S and Model X also saw significant price increases. These adjustments are attributed to intense demand outpacing production capabilities and ongoing supply-chain issues.

title: Opportunities in US stock market for investors who want to invest in climate change theme
summary: This article explores investment opportunities in the US stock market for those interested in the climate change theme, emphasizing the role of companies in mitigating climate risks and achieving long-term profitability. It highlights renewable energy, electric vehicles, and climate-focused Exchange Traded Funds (ETFs) as key investment avenues. The piece also provides specific company examples and discusses market growth projections for the renewable energy sector.

title: Caterpillar to move global headquarters from Illinois to Texas
summary: Caterpillar Inc. announced it is moving its global headquarters from Deerfield, Illinois, to Irving, Texas. The company declined to state the reason for the move or if it received incentives, though Texas is known for lower labor costs and less stringent regulation. This relocation follows a trend of other major manufacturers, like Boeing and Tesla, moving headquarters to Texas from other states.

title: Royal Caribbean may add Elon Musk's Starlink internet service to its cruise ships
summary: Royal Caribbean Group is exploring a partnership with Elon Musk's SpaceX to bring Starlink internet service to its cruise ships. The cruise line operator believes Starlink could significantly improve guest experience and business operations at sea, addressing current bandwidth constraints. This potential collaboration, if approved by the FCC, would be a first for the cruise industry and could set a new standard for internet connectivity on vessels.

title: Caterpillar headquarters leaving Illinois after nearly 100 years
summary: Caterpillar Inc. is moving its global headquarters from Deerfield, Illinois, to Irving, Texas, after nearly 100 years in its home state. The construction equipment manufacturer previously moved its base from Peoria, Illinois, to Deerfield in 2017. This move follows a trend of major corporations, including Boeing and several tech companies, relocating headquarters to Texas.

title: Royal Caribbean wants to add Elon Musk's Starlink high-speed internet to its cruise ships
summary: Royal Caribbean is seeking FCC approval to implement Elon Musk's Starlink high-speed internet on its cruise ships to significantly enhance onboard connectivity. This move aims to address current internet limitations and improve guest experience and business operations at sea. The adoption hinges on SpaceX receiving regulatory approval to operate Starlink on moving vehicles.

title: Musk wants to cut 10 percent of Tesla jobs: Report
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk reportedly has a "super bad feeling" about the economy and plans to cut about 10 percent of jobs at the electric carmaker, according to an email sent to executives. This message, titled "pause all hiring worldwide," follows his demand for staff to return to the workplace or leave, and comes amidst growing warnings from business leaders about a potential recession. The move has impacted Tesla's stock performance and is a more direct statement on the economic outlook than previous warnings from Musk.

title: Premarket Movers: Okta Cl A, HashiCorp Cl A, Kohl's Corp
summary: This article details pre-market stock movements for several companies. Okta Cl A and Kohl's Corp saw significant gains, up 16.2% and 7.3% respectively. Other companies like BRP, PagSeguro Digital, and Nutex Health also recorded gains, while HashiCorp Cl A and Tesla experienced declines.

title: U.S. safety regulators receive over 750 complaints of Teslas braking for no reason
summary: U.S. safety regulators have received over 750 complaints from Tesla owners reporting that their vehicles, operating on partially automated driving systems, suddenly stopped on roadways for no apparent reason. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) is investigating these "phantom braking" incidents in Models 3 and Y from 2021 and 2022, covering an estimated 416,000 vehicles. This is one of several ongoing investigations and recalls for Tesla by safety regulators.

title: What Does Amazon's Stock Split Mean for Investors?
summary: Amazon is executing a 20-1 stock split, its first in over two decades, effective June 3. The split will adjust Morningstar's fair value estimate for Amazon to $192 per share from $3,850, but senior analyst Dan Romanoff's long-term view remains unchanged, anticipating continued growth in e-commerce, AWS, and advertising. Other major tech companies like Alphabet and Tesla are also planning stock splits.

title: Tesla Fair Fund distributions established to pay 'harmed' investors
summary: The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission announced the establishment of the Tesla Fair Fund to distribute payments to investors harmed by Elon Musk's "funding secured" tweet. Investors who bought Tesla Inc. shares between August 7 and August 8, 2018, may be eligible for distributions. This fund was created after Tesla and CEO Elon Musk agreed to pay $40 million to settle an SEC lawsuit alleging the tweet was false and misleading.

title: Self-driving car companies' first step to making money isn't robotaxis
summary: Self-driving car companies are finding their initial path to profitability not through robotaxis, but through sales of driver-assistance software. Investment analysts from Goldman Sachs and Nomura highlight significant opportunities in auto software, with companies like WeRide partnering with Bosch to develop mass-production assisted driving systems. This L2/L3 market, particularly strong in China, offers clearer commercial value and a quicker revenue stream compared to fully autonomous robotaxi services.

title: Tesla Inc. stock outperforms competitors despite losses on the day
summary: Tesla Inc. stock (TSLA) fell 0.18% to $758.26 on Tuesday, May 31, 2022, despite an overall poor trading session for the stock market. The stock closed significantly below its 52-week high but outperformed some competitors, such as Toyota Motor Corp. ADR (TM) and Honda Motor Co. Ltd. ADR (HMC), although it lagged behind General Motors Co. (GM). Trading volume for Tesla exceeded its 50-day average.

title: 5 lessons I learned from helping to launch Tesla’s Model S
summary: The article shares five business lessons learned by Sukemasa Kabayama, the former President of Tesla Japan, during the challenging five-week launch of the Model S in Japan in 2014. These lessons emphasize creativity, holistic customer experience, laser focus on outcomes, the principle of "less is more," and clarity in problem-solving. Kabayama also draws parallels to his current startup, Uplift Labs.

title: Duke Energy Sustainable Solutions, BYU–Hawaii complete campuswide renewable energy system
summary: Duke Energy Sustainable Solutions and Brigham Young University–Hawaii have completed a campuswide renewable energy system, including solar and battery storage. This system is expected to meet 39% of the university's energy needs annually and save over $20 million in utility costs. The project aims to reduce the university's environmental impact and dependence on Hawaii's energy grid, utilizing a 20-year power purchase agreement to finance the initiative.

title: Tesla plans a drive-in movie restaurant in Hollywood
summary: Tesla has submitted documents to the city of Los Angeles for a 24-hour drive-in movie restaurant with a 28-stall Supercharger station in Hollywood, a concept Elon Musk has been teasing for four years. The plans detail a two-story diner with indoor and outdoor seating, two LED movie screens for drive-in viewing, and food delivery to cars. This futuristic establishment would replace a Shakey's Pizza and requires city approval before proceeding.

title: Lithium Miner Albemarle Lifts Outlook as EV Battery Demand Surges
summary: Albemarle Corp., the world’s largest lithium producer, has raised its financial outlook for the second time this month. This adjustment is due to strong demand for electric vehicle batteries and tight lithium supply, leading battery makers to pay higher prices for the metal. The company now projects sales between $5.8 billion and $6.2 billion for the current year.

title: Todd Rosenbluth Talks ESG, Tesla, and More on Bloomberg
summary: Todd Rosenbluth discussed the shifts in bond fund flows, the rise of defensive and value investment strategies, and the complexities surrounding Tesla's exclusion from the S&P 500 ESG index during his appearance on Bloomberg. He highlighted the importance of understanding the different components ("e," "s," and "g") of ESG and how momentum ETFs rebalance. Rosenbluth also emphasized that investors need to look beyond labels, as not all ESG or factor-based ETFs are the same.

title: Rosenbluth Discusses ESG, Tesla, and More on Bloomberg
summary: Todd Rosenbluth recently appeared on Bloomberg to discuss various ETF-related topics, including the growing appeal of low-cost bond ETFs over mutual funds, defensive and factor investing strategies, and specific ETF rebalances. He also addressed why Tesla was dropped from the S&P 500 ESG index, emphasizing the differentiation between environmental, social, and governance factors. Rosenbluth highlighted the importance of looking beyond labels for ESG ETFs, as they can differ significantly.

title: A superstar investor with the Midas touch or just lucky? The puzzle of Cathie Wood
summary: Cathie Wood, CEO of ARK Invest, became a superstar investor during the pandemic with her ARK Innovation ETF returning 150% in 2020. However, her funds are struggling significantly in 2022, leading to questions about her investment strategy and whether her past success was due to skill or luck. Despite criticism and poor performance, Wood remains confident, advocating for a five-year investment horizon and continuing to attract new investor money.

title: Innovation Meets Productivity at AGCO Jackson Campus
summary: The article highlights the AGCO Jackson campus as a world-class manufacturing facility for agricultural machinery, emphasizing its focus on innovation, productivity, and a strong employee culture. It details why Jackson, Minnesota, was chosen for the plant, the importance of its workforce in agricultural production, and how the company is adapting to new challenges like supply chain issues and evolving market trends by prioritizing "farmer first" solutions and behavioral hiring.

title: Tesla dumped by S&P ESG index as Musk calls label a ‘scam’
summary: Tesla has been removed from the S&P 500 ESG Index due to concerns regarding working conditions, its handling of investigations into driver-assistance system deaths, and a lack of low-carbon strategy and business conduct codes. While S&P Dow Jones Indices noted Tesla's ESG score remained "fairly stable," it slipped against improving global peers. CEO Elon Musk subsequently criticized ESG as a "scam" and "fundamentally flawed," stating it has been "weaponized by phony social justice warriors."

title: Tesla targets Silver Spring for new service center
summary: Tesla Inc. is planning to open a new service center in Silver Spring, Maryland, expanding its presence in the Greater Washington area. The electric automaker will lease a single-story office building for this new facility. This move signifies Tesla's continued growth and investment in its service infrastructure.

title: Bill Gates Sells $940 Million of CN Rail Stock
summary: Bill Gates' investment firm, Cascade Investment, sold approximately $940 million worth of Canadian National Railway Co. shares between April 27 and May 12, reducing its stake in the company to about 9%. This sale is part of an ongoing reduction in ownership since May 2021. Gates' former wife, Melinda French Gates, and the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation also sold significant portions of their Canadian National shares.

title: Netflix and TikTok Cultures Reveal the Dark Side of Innovation
summary: This article explores the demanding work cultures at highly innovative companies like Netflix and TikTok, highlighting the "dark side of innovation." It discusses how the relentless pursuit of growth and excellence leads to long hours, poor work-life balance, and employee burnout, despite the prestige and career opportunities offered. The article contrasts the inspiring public image of innovation with the personal costs borne by employees in these fast-paced environments.

title: Tesla recalls 130,000 EVs for touch screen malfunctions
summary: Tesla is recalling approximately 130,000 electric vehicles in the US due to touch screens that can overheat and go blank, affecting certain Model S, Model X, Model 3, and Model Y vehicles. The issue stems from insufficient cooling of central processing units during fast charging, which can lead to slow screens or blank displays, potentially increasing crash risk. Tesla is addressing the problem with online software updates to improve temperature management, having already initiated updates on May 3.

title: When Momentum Fails
summary: The article discusses how momentum, a historically strong investment factor, has shown signs of faltering in recent months despite its long-term outperformance. It highlights that while momentum stocks have often delivered strong returns, periods of market decline and shifts in investor sentiment can lead to sharp drawdowns, emphasizing that nothing lasts forever in investing.

title: Time might be right to take ride in convertibles
summary: Tracy Maitland suggests that convertible bonds offer institutional investors a valuable way to diversify their fixed-income portfolios, especially given the current low returns from core strategies. The article highlights the potential of convertibles as a strategic asset in challenging market conditions.

title: Tesla’s 10-Word Rule Every Employee Has to Follow Is Simply Brilliant
summary: This article discusses Tesla's "do the right thing" aspiration as outlined in its 2021 Impact Report, highlighting how this simple 10-word phrase serves as a core principle for all employees. It explains that this aspiration encourages self-awareness within the company, guiding decisions related to hiring, customer interaction, and overall leadership. The author emphasizes that this principle helps define the company's direction and sets clear expectations for every team member.

title: Brazil's Vale signs long-term deal to supply Tesla with nickel
summary: Brazilian mining company Vale SA has signed a long-term deal to supply Tesla Inc with low-carbon Class 1 nickel from its Canadian operations. This agreement aligns with Vale's strategy to increase its exposure to the electric vehicle industry, aiming for 30% to 40% of its Class 1 nickel sales to go to this fast-growing sector. The nickel supplied will come from Vale's Long Harbour plant in Newfoundland and Labrador, which produces nickel rounds with a low carbon footprint.

title: China’s COVID hard line eats into everything from Teslas to tacos
summary: China's strict 'zero COVID' policies have severely impacted various industries, from luxury goods to fast-food restaurants, causing significant lost sales and shaken consumer confidence. Lockdowns, particularly in Shanghai, have disrupted supply chains and drastically reduced demand for products like electric vehicles, with analysts warning of a growing risk of recession. While some cities are offering incentives to boost spending, the prolonged impact of pandemic controls continues to threaten the consumer sector across China.

title: US plug-in vehicle sales hit a record high in Q1, led by Tesla and California
summary: US plug-in vehicle sales reached a record high in Q1, driven significantly by Tesla and California. Nationally, approximately 208,000 electric vehicles were sold, with California accounting for about 40% of these sales. Tesla maintained a substantial lead, especially in California, where its Model 3 and Model Y topped sales charts.

title: Cyber Risk for Vehicles
summary: This article discusses the increasing cyber risks associated with the fast-paced evolution of vehicle automation and internet-connected technologies. It categorizes intelligent vehicles and outlines the emerging risks related to privacy, security, and safety, highlighting vulnerabilities in vehicle software. The article also touches upon the implications for motor insurance, distinguishing between tangible property loss and pure financial loss exposures.

title: How to Invest in Lithium in Latin America
summary: This article explores investment opportunities in the lithium industry, particularly in Latin America, where 50% of the world’s lithium reserves are located across Argentina, Bolivia, and Chile. It discusses investing through ETFs like Lithium & Battery Tech (LIT) and individual company shares such as Albemarle (ALB), Tesla (TSLA), TDK, Sociedad Química y Minera de Chile SA (SQM), and Posco, highlighting their performance and market trends. The piece also delves into the complexities of the lithium market, the impact of electric vehicle demand, and future price sustainability.

title: Invesco launches ETF focused on metals required for electric vehicles, energy transition
summary: Invesco has launched a new exchange-traded fund (ETF) called the Invesco Electric Vehicle Metals Commodity Strategy No K-1 ETF (EVMT), which focuses on metals critical for electric vehicles and the energy transition. The fund holds futures contracts for aluminum, copper, nickel, cobalt, zinc, and iron ore, excluding lithium due to liquidity concerns. This launch comes amid soaring metals prices and growing demand as the EV market expands, with Invesco betting on continued volatility and growth in the sector.

title: Does a Musk-owned Twitter dim Tesla’s star?
summary: Elon Musk's bid to buy Twitter has raised concerns about its potential impact on Tesla's reputation and future. Observers question whether this acquisition distracts Musk from Tesla's core mission and if the controversies surrounding Twitter could negatively affect the automaker's brand and stock performance. While some see potential for new alliances and free speech advocacy, others worry about conflicts of interest and potential harm to customer perception and privacy.

title: Can Elon Musk Run Tesla, Twitter and SpaceX? We’ll Soon Find Out.
summary: Elon Musk's ability to simultaneously lead Tesla, Twitter, and SpaceX is being questioned as he takes on another major project with the Twitter acquisition. Despite previously lamenting his lack of time, Musk has a track record of successfully juggling multiple ventures, including achieving a record profit at Tesla, securing financing for Twitter, and promoting his other companies. The article sets the stage for observing how he manages these demanding roles.

title: Tax Breaks Cushion Tesla’s Texas Landing
summary: Tesla received approximately $64 million in state and local tax breaks to build its Giga Texas factory in Austin, sparking debate over the efficacy of such incentives in generating promised economic benefits and jobs. The article highlights concerns that communities often give up more than they gain from these deals, drawing parallels to Tesla's Buffalo factory where job creation targets were not met. Community groups and local residents have raised issues regarding the deal's lack of oversight, potential for wage theft and unsafe conditions, and the challenge of local hiring due to language barriers, leading some local lawmakers to question the wisdom of future incentive deals.

title: Twitter kicks off deal negotiations with Tesla boss Musk: Report
summary: Twitter Inc. has begun deal negotiations with Elon Musk following his $43 billion acquisition offer, which he supported with financing details to woo shareholders. While the decision to engage does not guarantee acceptance of his $54.20 per share bid, it indicates Twitter is exploring the possibility of a sale on attractive terms. The social media company is also scrutinizing potential regulatory investigations into Musk and discussing concerns about a "poison pill" defense and a possible tender offer.

title: An entertainment company is using Twitter Spaces for its next earnings call—with 'Litquidity' as the moderator
summary: RCI Hospitality Holdings, Inc., led by CEO Eric Langan, plans to host its upcoming earnings call on Twitter Spaces, aiming to reach a younger demographic and retail investors. This initiative, moderated by "Litquidity," is believed to be a first for earnings calls on the platform. The company believes this new format will increase engagement and visibility for its financial results.

title: Tesla Insurance Adds 3 More States, Plans to be Nationwide This Year
summary: Tesla is expanding its insurance product to Colorado, Oregon, and Virginia, with plans to be nationwide by the end of the year. The company bases its rates on a driver's "Safety Score" calculated by in-car computers, aiming to save average drivers around 30 percent compared to competitors. Tesla Insurance aims to streamline the claims process through its app and help recover deductibles for not-at-fault accidents.

title: Here's Why Elon Musk May Start Mining His Own Lithium
summary: Elon Musk is calling for increased investment in lithium mining due to a significant supply-demand gap fueled by the rise of electric vehicles. Facing skyrocketing prices and a concentrated global supply, the Tesla chief suggested the company might begin mining its own lithium, a plan he first hinted at two years ago. The slow growth in lithium supply is attributed to a lack of investment following previous boom-bust cycles and the reliance on traditional mining countries, as newer, greener technologies have yet to reach commercial scale.

title: Self-driving Cars, Rare Earth Metals, ESG Activism: New ETFs On Syfe
summary: Syfe has introduced three new ETFs to its platform: IDRV (iShares Self-Driving EV and Tech ETF), REMX (VanEck Rare Earth/Strategic Metals ETF), and VOTE (Engine No. 1 Transform 500 ETF). These ETFs offer investors exposure to rapidly growing sectors such as electric vehicles and autonomous driving, critical rare earth metals, and shareholder activism focused on ESG initiatives. The article details the holdings, market outlook, and expense ratios for each of these new investment options.

title: Elon Musk's Tesla Races Ahead of Rising Costs With Price Hikes
summary: Tesla's Q1 results surged past Wall Street expectations, with higher prices helping the company overcome supply chain issues and rising costs. CEO Elon Musk indicated Tesla has a reasonable shot at achieving 60% vehicle delivery growth this year and that price increases effectively cover cost inflation. The strong performance also triggers $23 billion in new payouts for Musk, as the company navigates production challenges with its new factories and supply chain constraints.
source: VOA - Voice of America English News
source_domain: VOA - Voice of America English News

title: New 'black gold' of Alabama to put state on map for automakers |…
summary: Alabama is set to become a major player in the automotive industry due to the discovery of a significant graphite deposit in the state, dubbed "black gold." Westwater Resources, Inc. and Alabama Graphite are building the first graphite processing plant of its kind in the US, which will produce refined graphite for lithium-ion batteries used in electric vehicles. This development positions Alabama to reduce foreign dependence on graphite and become a global leader in the EV supply chain.

title: Tesla profits surge as EV maker races past rising material costs
summary: Tesla Inc. surpassed Wall Street estimates for quarterly revenue and profit, driven by price increases that offset rising material costs and a factory shutdown in Shanghai. Despite global supply chain issues and chip shortages, the EV maker saw its shares rise and revenue hit $18.8 billion in the first quarter of 2022, up 81 percent from the previous year. New factories in Berlin and Texas are expected to help meet demand and reduce reliance on its China factory.

title: Netflix shares fall more than 35% after streamer loses over 200,000 subscribers
summary: Netflix shares plummeted over 35% after the company announced a loss of more than 200,000 subscribers in Q1 2022 and projected a further 2 million loss. This significant drop, wiping $50bn off its value, is attributed to increased competition, market saturation post-pandemic, inflation, and account sharing. Netflix plans to address this by tackling account sharing, improving programming quality, and considering an advertiser-supported subscription tier.

title: Tesla vehicles can no longer be bought at the end of their lease
summary: Tesla has updated its policy, stating that vehicles delivered on or after April 15, 2022, are no longer eligible for purchase at the end of their lease. This decision comes amidst skyrocketing used-car prices and a history of Tesla occasionally withholding lease-end purchase options, particularly for the Model 3 for its intended "robotaxi" network. The change means third-party dealerships and individuals also cannot purchase leased Teslas, which may be influenced by the ongoing surge in both new and used EV prices.

title: NHTSA Opens Two Defect Investigations Into Tesla Autopilot
summary: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has launched two formal defect investigations into Tesla's Autopilot system after multiple incidents where Teslas using the system collided with first-responder vehicles, including a fatal crash. This increased scrutiny could lead to recalls, tarnish Tesla's reputation, and highlights growing tensions between the company and regulators regarding the safety of its driver-assistance technologies. Critics argue that Tesla's approach is riskier compared to other automakers and that the current regulatory landscape in the U.S. has allowed for a "Wild West" environment for such technologies.

title: GM CEO Mary Barra talks newest electric vehicle, inflation and competition with Tesla
summary: GM CEO Mary Barra discussed the company's newest EV, the Cadillac LYRIQ, and their commitment to an all-electric future by 2035. She addressed current inflation and high gas prices, noting increased consumer interest in EVs, and outlined GM's plans to expand charging infrastructure. Barra also expressed confidence in GM's ability to compete with Tesla and capture a significant share of the growing EV market.

title: The Biggest Reveals from Bitcoin 2022
summary: The Bitcoin 2022 conference in Miami highlighted the early stage of Bitcoin adoption, with comparisons drawn to the internet in 1995. Key announcements included Robinhood rolling out crypto wallets and Lightning Network integration, new jurisdictions like Prospera (Honduras) and Madeira adopting Bitcoin as legal tender, and Strike partnering with major point-of-sale systems like Shopify and McDonald's to facilitate Bitcoin payments. The article emphasizes Bitcoin's potential for mass adoption and its disruptive impact on payment processing.

title: 3 Reasons Why Investors Are Adding Digital Assets Exposure
summary: Investors are increasingly adding digital assets to their portfolios for three main reasons: their transformative impact on economic activity, their potential to hedge against inflation (especially assets with finite supplies like Bitcoin), and their ability to further diversify a portfolio. The article highlights ETFs such as SATO and BLKC as ways for investors to gain exposure to this growing asset class.

title: Samsung Asset Management gets 20% equity stake in Amplify
summary: Samsung Asset Management has acquired a 20% equity stake in Amplify. The deal was reported on April 1, 2022, and was featured in Pensions & Investments.

title: GameStop Soars on Plans to Extend Rebound With Stock Split
summary: GameStop (GME) shares soared by as much as 22% in extended trading following the announcement of plans to propose a stock split to shareholders in the form of a dividend. The company intends to ask for approval to increase its Class A shares from 300 million to 1 billion at its upcoming annual meeting. This move led to a significant jump in the stock price, reaching $203.98 after closing at $166.58.

title: Move Electric Awards 2022 E-Leader of the Year: Graeme Cooper
summary: Graeme Cooper, Head of Future Markets at National Grid, was named Move Electric Awards 2022 E-Leader of the Year for his work in preparing the energy system for a greener future and increased EV adoption. He emphasizes that the National Grid can cope with a mass switch to EVs and is managing a comprehensive transition across various sectors, not just cars. Cooper, an EV owner himself, actively debunks myths about the grid's readiness for the energy transition.

title: Sunrun stays atop US residential solar market in 2021, Tesla out of top three
summary: Sunrun maintained its leading position in the US residential solar market in 2021. Meanwhile, Tesla dropped out of the top three companies in the sector. This indicates a shift in market dominance within the residential solar industry.

title: Lotus Electric SUV Is a Lean, Mean, China-Made Driving Machine
summary: The Lotus Eletre, a 600-horsepower electric SUV, marks a significant shift for the British sports car brand towards "lifestyle" vehicles and mass relevancy. Majority stakeholder Zhejiang Geely Holding Group Co. unveiled the China-made Eletre, which goes zero to 60 mph in three seconds, as the first of a series of new EVs planned for the coming years. This move aims to expand Lotus's market presence beyond its traditional track-tuned sports cars.

title: The ALPS Clean Energy ETF rises on energy shift to renewables
summary: The ALPS Clean Energy ETF (ACES) has seen a significant rise in its share price due to the accelerated global shift towards renewable energy, influenced by factors like Russia's invasion of Ukraine. This conflict has highlighted the need for greater energy diversification and prompted countries to reduce reliance on Russian oil and gas. Despite the ETF having a year-to-date daily loss, its key holdings in solar, wind, and electric vehicle sectors, including Enphase Energy, Plug Power, and Tesla, are benefiting from increased investment and customer demand.

title: HP finance manager went on $5m personal spending spree with company card
summary: Shelbee Szeto, a former HP finance planning manager, pleaded guilty to wire fraud, money laundering, and filing false tax returns after misappropriating approximately $5.2 million from the company. Szeto used company PCards to make payments to her own merchant accounts, then spent the funds on luxury items like Tesla and Porsche vehicles, high-end bags, and jewelry. Her sentencing is scheduled for July 20, 2022.

title: POSCO Holdings Inc. Invests U$839 million in Lithium business in Argentina
summary: POSCO Holdings Inc. is investing U$839 million in a lithium plant in Argentina, aiming to produce 25,000 tons of lithium hydroxide annually by 2024, with plans to expand to 100,000 tons by 2028. This move strengthens POSCO Group's position in the electric vehicle battery material market, leveraging significant lithium reserves in Argentina. The company also secured cooperation with the Argentine government for further business expansion.

title: Li Auto to raise price of Li ONE from April 1
summary: Li Auto announced it will increase the price of its Li ONE model by RMB 11,800 starting April 1, 2022, citing a sharp rise in raw material prices. This follows similar price adjustments by other EV manufacturers like Tesla, Xpeng, and BYD, all attributing the increases to rising raw material costs, particularly for batteries. While Li Auto and Xpeng are raising prices, Nio has stated it currently has no plans to do so.

title: Annual Truck, RV & Car Warranty Trends, 17 March 2022
summary: This article analyzes annual warranty trends for passenger cars, RVs, and trucks in the U.S. automotive industry for 2021. It examines claims, accruals, and expense rates for key manufacturers like Ford, GM, Tesla, Thor, Winnebago, Caterpillar, and Deere, highlighting how these metrics compare to sales growth. The report notes a general trend of declining warranty expenses relative to rising sales, though with some notable exceptions and varying patterns across segments.

title: New Investments Ready to Propel AV Technology Forward
summary: New investments are rapidly advancing autonomous vehicle (AV) technology, with major automakers and tech companies pouring billions into R&D to enhance safety and performance. While full autonomy and mass adoption are long-term goals due to testing, regulatory, and infrastructure challenges, early commercial applications like robotaxis present immediate growth opportunities. The article details technological advancements, investment trends, regulatory hurdles, consumer acceptance, and the potential for AVs to revolutionize transportation.

title: The Zacks Analyst Blog Highlights Chevron, Exxon Mobil, Tesla, Target Corp, and Marriott International
summary: This Zacks Analyst Blog highlights five U.S. corporate giants—Chevron, Exxon Mobil, Tesla, Target Corp, and Marriott International—as strong buy recommendations despite current market volatility, inflation, and geopolitical tensions. These companies are identified for their strong fundamentals, positive earnings estimate revisions, and solid growth potential. The article provides a detailed analysis of why each company is a compelling investment, citing their business models, market positioning, and financial outlook amidst challenging economic conditions.

title: CERAWEEK PG&E partners with Ford Motor on bidirectional EV charging
summary: California utility PG&E Corp is partnering with Ford Motor Co to bring bidirectional charging electric vehicles (EVs) to its customers, allowing EVs like the Ford F-150 Lightning to power homes for several days. This pilot program aims to test how these vehicles can support grid reliability by providing backup power. Ford CEO Jim Farley stated that the company plans to make most of its EVs bidirectional, distinguishing its approach from Tesla's due to its energy business.
banner_image: FILE PHOTO: The charging socket is seen on Ford Motor Co's electric Mustang Mach-E vehicle during a photo shoot at a studio in Warren, Michigan, U.S. October 29, 2019. REUTERS/Rebecca Cook/File Photo/File Photo

title: Amazon announces 20-for-1 stock split
summary: Amazon announced a 20-for-1 stock split, following similar moves by other major tech companies like Alphabet, Apple, and Tesla. The article explains that a stock split divides existing shares into multiple, smaller-priced shares without changing the overall value of an investor's holdings or the company's market capitalization. Stock splits are often done to increase a stock's liquidity and make it more accessible to a wider range of investors, though in an era of fractional shares, some of the practical impact is diminished.

title: BNY Mellon taps next CEO
summary: BNY Mellon has announced its next CEO. The article title "BNY Mellon taps next CEO" and mentions Thomas P. “Todd” Gibbons and Robin Vince, indicating a leadership change at the company.

title: Why Hasn’t Cathie Wood’s ARK Fund Invested in Quantum Computing or Quantum Technologies?
summary: This article questions why Cathie Wood's ARK Fund, known for investing in disruptive innovations, has not invested in quantum computing or quantum technologies, despite the industry fitting ARK's investment criteria. It explores potential reasons such as the nascent and highly theoretical nature of the quantum industry, and lack of clear commercial viability from ARK's perspective. The author concludes that based on publicly available criteria, the quantum industry appears to be a suitable investment for ARK.

title: E.C.D. Builds the Classic Defender of Your Fantasies
summary: E.C.D. Automotive Design, formerly East Coast Defenders, has grown into a significant bespoke vehicle business, restoring and customizing Land Rovers, including a new Tesla-powered electric drivetrain option. The company emphasizes quality, efficiency, and extensive customer customization, producing high-end Defenders that blend classic charm with modern amenities. Despite the high price tag, E.C.D. offers an exclusive and well-executed driving experience that new SUVs cannot replicate.

title: Grupo México de Larrea y Telesites de Slim impulsan cierre ganador de la BMV
summary: The Mexican Stock Exchange (BMV) closed with gains, driven by companies like Grupo México and Telesites, as oil prices receded. In contrast, Wall Street indices ended lower, and oil prices also fell due to investor concerns about inflation, Federal Reserve policy, and the impact of the Russia-Ukraine conflict on commodity markets. The article also details the performance of various companies on both the BMV and Wall Street, as well as the impact on global markets and bond yields.

title: DoD Awards $35 Million to MP Materials to Build U.S. Heavy Rare Earth Separation Capacity
summary: The Department of Defense has awarded MP Materials Corp. a $35 million contract to construct a heavy rare earth element (HREE) separation facility at its Mountain Pass, California site. This initiative aims to establish domestic HREE processing capabilities, supporting U.S. defense and commercial applications and strengthening America's supply chains. The project seeks to reduce reliance on international markets for these critical materials, which are essential for various technologies including electric vehicles and wind turbines.

title: Sustainable Funds Landscape - Highlights and Observations
summary: The article highlights the continued growth and strong performance of sustainable funds in 2021, with nearly $70 billion in new investments and returns generally outpacing conventional funds. It emphasizes the need for greater transparency in sustainable investing, urging funds to clearly describe their approaches and impact beyond financial returns, an issue becoming more critical given the increasing investor interest. The author also delves into different types of sustainable funds and the importance of understanding their diverse strategies.

title: Cathie Wood went on TV to defend her ARK funds’ bad performance. It didn’t go as planned
summary: Cathie Wood appeared on CNBC's Halftime Report to defend the poor performance of her ARK Innovation ETF (ARKK), which was down 30% year to date. She asserted that the fund's holdings were "way undervalued" and that recent losses were temporary, despite the ARKK ETF declining significantly from its peak. The interview drew attention for its timing, a Zoom call interruption, and Wood's dismissal of the inverse SARK ETF.

title: Rivian stock surges after George Soros' fund disclosed $2 billion investment
summary: Rivian stock saw a significant surge after news broke that George Soros' fund had disclosed a roughly $2 billion investment in the electric vehicle manufacturer. The investment, revealed via a December 2021 report, contributed to a 12% jump in Rivian shares, although the exact timing and purchase price of the shares remain unknown. This positive sentiment was further bolstered by Amazon's previous investment and contractual agreement with Rivian for 100,000 electric vehicles.

title: Federal prosecutors say a former HP worker scammed the company out of $4.8M and used it to buy a Tesla
summary: Federal prosecutors have accused Shelbee Szeto, a former HP employee, of scamming the company out of $4.8 million. Szeto allegedly routed corporate money to her personal bank account and used it to purchase luxury items including a Tesla, jewelry, and handbags. The complaint was filed on Friday, February 11, 2022.

title: Snow Lake Lithium is developing the world's first all-electric lithium mine to support EV industry in North America
summary: Snow Lake Resources Ltd. is developing the world's first all-electric lithium mine in Manitoba, Canada, aiming to supply the North American EV industry with sustainably sourced, carbon-neutral lithium. The company seeks a joint venture partner to process the raw lithium into EV batteries and intends to cut dependency on foreign supply chains. The project emphasizes environmentally friendly mining practices, utilizing hydroelectricity and electric mining equipment.

title: Ferrari takes Qualcomm on board to tackle digitalisation
summary: Qualcomm Technologies and Ferrari N.V. have formed a strategic technology collaboration to advance Ferrari’s digital transformation. Qualcomm will serve as the systems solutions provider for future Ferrari road cars, leveraging its Snapdragon Digital Chassis for telematics, digital cockpit, and ADAS capabilities. Additionally, Qualcomm Technologies will become a premium partner for the Scuderia Ferrari Formula One team and the Ferrari eSports team, with the Snapdragon logo featured on the new F1 race cars.

title: Hertz names ex-Goldman finance chief Stephen Scherr as CEO
summary: Hertz Global Holdings has appointed Stephen Scherr, former Goldman Sachs CFO, as its new chief executive officer, effective end of February. Scherr replaces interim CEO Mark Fields and joins Hertz during a pivotal time as the company electrifies its fleet, including a significant deal to acquire 100,000 Tesla vehicles. This leadership change and strategic direction follow Hertz's emergence from bankruptcy and a strong rebound in demand.

title: General Motors Wants to Hire 8,000 Highly Skilled Workers, Technologists
summary: General Motors announced plans to hire 8,000 highly skilled workers, including software developers and computer scientists, in 2022 to boost its technological capabilities and compete with companies like Tesla. While GM aims to innovate, it faces challenges in attracting top talent due to lower compensation compared to tech giants and Tesla, possibly relying on benefits and perks instead. The automotive industry is increasingly investing in advanced car technologies, making the acquisition of skilled technologists crucial for future success.

title: Jim Cramer says the SARK ETF is trying to benefit from the struggles of high-growth stocks
summary: Jim Cramer highlighted the Tuttle Capital Short Innovation ETF (SARK), which aims to profit from the decline of previously high-flying growth stocks, particularly those found in Cathie Wood's ARK Innovation ETF. SARK was up 38.23% year to date as of the article's publication, while the Nasdaq Composite was down 14.65%. Cramer suggests investors build core portfolios of profitable companies and consider SARK to hedge against continued struggles in growth stocks.

title: Tesla won't roll out new models in 2022 because of chip shortages
summary: Tesla will not roll out any new models in 2022, including the delayed Cybertruck, due to the global chip shortage, according to CEO Elon Musk. Despite this, Tesla reported record fourth-quarter and full-year earnings, with $5.5 billion in profit for 2021 as vehicle deliveries soared. The company plans to focus on existing models and explore new factory locations, while its "Full Self-Driving" software is now being tested by nearly 60,000 users.

title: CES 2022 Recap: Tech Becoming More Accessible and Interoperable
summary: CES 2022 showcased significant advancements making technology more accessible and interoperable. Key trends included enhanced immersion in the metaverse with new AR/VR products, traditional auto OEMs committing to mass-market electric vehicles, and the emergence of a unified Internet of Things ecosystem through initiatives like Matter. The event highlighted a shift towards practical, everyday applications for emerging technologies, signaling potential disruptions in various sectors.

title: Warren Buffett has nearly caught up with Cathie Wood after the tech-stock guru vastly outperformed him in 2020
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway has nearly caught up to Cathie Wood's Ark Innovation ETF in terms of performance since the start of 2020, narrowing the gap from over 200 percentage points to just 5. While Wood's fund soared during the initial pandemic tech boom, it has since fallen due to investors pulling out of growth stocks in anticipation of interest-rate hikes. This shift highlights the differing investment strategies of Buffett's value-oriented approach and Wood's focus on disruptive growth companies.

title: Electric Vehicles and Getting Beyond Tesla
summary: This article discusses the growth opportunities in electric vehicles and the new transportation technology ecosystem, along with investment strategies. It highlights the role of the KraneShares Electric Vehicles and Future Mobility ETF (NYSE: KARS) in capturing this potential, projecting significant growth in EV sales and investment by 2040. The piece invites financial advisors to a webcast for more insights.

title: Accelerating EV Charging Installations
summary: Southern California Edison (SCE) is significantly increasing its electric vehicle (EV) charging infrastructure, planning to install 8,000 new charging ports annually over the next few years. This initiative is part of an effort to address the availability barrier of EV charging stations, as highlighted by Edison International President and CEO Pedro Pizarro at the National EV Charging Summit. SCE's Charge Ready programs aim to support widespread EV adoption by providing charging options in various locations, including underserved communities, and for both light-duty and heavy-duty vehicles.

title: TrueCar (TRUE) Founder's New Venture Will Get You a Tesla (TSLA) in 10 Minutes
summary: Scott Painter, founder of TrueCar Inc., has launched a new subscription service called "Autonomy" that offers Tesla Model 3 sedans for a flat monthly fee. This service aims to provide a new option for drivers who want to experience a Tesla without the commitment of ownership. Autonomy has already acquired approximately 100 Tesla vehicles for its program, which begins in California.

title: About
summary: QuantumScape is dedicated to revolutionizing energy storage with its solid-state battery technology, aiming to power a decarbonized future, starting with transportation. Founded in 2010, the company has developed a patented solid ceramic electrolyte separator that enables fast-charging, long-lasting, and safer batteries by utilizing a lithium-metal anode. This breakthrough technology is designed to simplify manufacturing, increase energy density, and provide enhanced safety compared to conventional lithium-ion batteries.

title: Here’s Why the UPRO and TQQQ Stock Prices Fell 50.1% Premarket Despite Calm Markets
summary: The ProShares UltraPro S&P500 (UPRO) and ProShares UltraPro QQQ (TQQQ) ETFs both fell about 50% in premarket trading. This significant drop was due to previously announced forward stock splits by ProShares, intended to make the shares more affordable to a wider range of investors, not due to market instability. The splits ensure the total value of investors' holdings remains unchanged, similar to traditional stock splits seen with companies like Apple and Tesla.

title: Blink Charging Launches Seven Next-Generation EV Charging Products
summary: Blink Charging Co. unveiled seven new EV charging products and two new apps at CES, marking an unprecedented achievement for the company. These next-generation solutions cater to various sectors including home, fleet, multifamily, and retail, enhancing the EV charging ecosystem. The new offerings, including the MQ 200, HQ 200, Vision IQ 200, 50kW DC Fast Charger, Blink Mobile App, and Blink Fleet portal, aim to provide a more seamless, efficient, and affordable charging experience for consumers and fleets.

title: Hesai Technology showcased new automotive-grade hybrid solid-state Lidar AT128
summary: Hesai Technology showcased its new automotive-grade hybrid solid-state lidar AT128 at CES 2022. This long-range sensor is designed for L3+ ADAS applications in mass production vehicles, featuring image-level resolution, superior ranging capability, and automotive-grade reliability, with mass production slated for 2022. Hesai also unveiled the QT128, a short-range lidar aimed at L4 applications, entering mass production in Q1 2023.

title: Visteon Showcases Wireless Battery Management System
summary: Visteon Corp. showcased its smart wireless battery management system (BMS) for electric vehicles at CES 2022. This system replaces wired connections with secure communication technology, reducing assembly time, overall vehicle weight, and offering scalability across different vehicle segments. Visteon's CEO, Sachin Lawande, highlights how this innovation streamlines EV manufacturing and enhances the ownership experience.

title: GM To Use Qualcomm' Snapdragon Ride Platform For Advanced Driver Assistance Technology
summary: General Motors (GM) will incorporate Qualcomm's Snapdragon Ride Platform for its next-generation Ultra Cruise hands-free driver-assist system, making it the first to utilize this advanced technology. The system, featuring a powerful 5-nanometer SoC and AI accelerator, will be available in 2023 on Cadillac LYRIQ and CELESTIQ models. This move significantly enhances GM's autonomous driving capabilities.

title: Disruptive Growth Will Require Patience, but Potential Rewards Lurk
summary: This article discusses disruptive growth strategies, particularly focusing on the ARK Innovation ETF (ARKK), which faced a downturn in 2021 and early 2022 due to anticipated Federal Reserve rate tightening. Despite recent struggles, the article argues that the long-term thesis for disruptive technologies, addressing the fourth industrial revolution, remains intact. It highlights five major themes identified by RBC as future disruptors and notes ARKK's exposure to many of these areas through its holdings like Tesla (TSLA) and Shopify (SHOP).

title: Machine Customers Will Decide Who Gets Their Trillion-Dollar Business. Is It You?
summary: The article explores the rise of "machine customers" and their potential to drive a trillion-dollar business opportunity. It outlines how these nonhuman entities, ranging from bound to autonomous customers, make purchasing decisions differently from humans by being transparent, processing vast amounts of data, and prioritizing efficiency over emotional loyalty. Businesses must adapt their corporate strategy, sales, marketing, and data analytics to cater to this evolving market.

title: VINFAST ANNOUNCES ITS ALL ELECTRIC STRATEGY AND FULL ELECTRIC VEHICLE LINEUP AT CES 2022
summary: VinFast announced its comprehensive all-electric strategy and full electric vehicle lineup at CES 2022, revealing plans to cease internal combustion engine (ICE) car production by late 2022 and transition entirely to EVs. The company launched five electric SUV models (VF 5, VF 6, VF 7, VF 8, VF 9) across segments A-E and opened reservations for the VF 8 and VF 9 with a special gratitude program for early customers. VinFast also introduced an innovative battery lease program and will apply blockchain technology for orders, reinforcing its commitment to sustainable mobility.

title: Qualcomm inks car chip deals with Volvo, Honda and Renault
summary: Qualcomm announced deals to supply chips to automakers Volvo Group, Honda Motor Co Ltd, and Renault SA, accelerating its push into the automotive sector. The company will provide its "Snapdragon Cockpit" chips for digital dashboards and infotainment systems, aiming to help car manufacturers transform vehicles into rolling computers capable of over-the-air updates and generating recurring revenue. Qualcomm also unveiled a new chip and system, "Snapdragon Ride Vision System," for computer vision and safety features, utilizing technology from its recent acquisition of Arriver.

title: Commentary: Why Vietnam’s electric carmaker VinFast is launching in the US and bypassing China
summary: Vietnamese electric carmaker VinFast is strategically launching its EVs in the US market, bypassing China despite its size, to achieve global brand recognition and leverage high American technological standards. The company aims to compete with established EV players like Tesla and Rivian by focusing on experimental innovation and competitive pricing, particularly targeting the trend-setting California market. This move represents a gamble on branding for a start-up, hoping that not being tied to traditional automotive roots will be an asset.

title: Elon Musk: I'm almost done with Tesla stock sales
summary: Elon Musk, CEO of Tesla Inc., indicated on Wednesday that he is "almost done" with his Tesla stock sales, which have exceeded $15 billion since early November. He clarified that he had sold enough to reach approximately 10% of his shares, including option exercises, driven in part by expiring stock options and tax obligations. Musk also criticized California's "overtaxation" and "overregulation," stating he would pay over $11 billion in taxes this year.

title: Volta bets on space technology for battery storage fire prevention
summary: Energy storage developer Volta Energy Products has partnered with KULR Technology Group to integrate KULR's space technology-derived thermal safety solutions into battery storage units. This collaboration aims to prevent thermal runaway in lithium-ion batteries, making energy storage safer and potentially less expensive by reducing the need for external fire suppression. The partnership marks the first application of KULR's passive propagation resistant (PPR) solution for energy storage, with Volta planning to deploy thousands of units incorporating this technology in the coming years.

title: Tesla secures another order of electric semi trucks
summary: Karat Packaging has announced an order for 10 Tesla Semi trucks to electrify its logistics fleet, indicating continued demand for Tesla's electric Class 8 semis despite production delays. This order highlights Karat Packaging's commitment to environmentally friendly solutions and expanding its 3PL services. The timeline for delivery remains uncertain, especially as other major reservation holders like PepsiCo have conflicting expectations regarding their first deliveries.

title: Indian-Origin CEO Gets $2.3 Billon Pay Package from Bill Gates Backed Energy Storage Co.
summary: Jagdeep Singh, the Indian-origin CEO of QuantumScape Corp., a US-based energy storage startup backed by Bill Gates, is set to receive a compensation package estimated at $2.3 billion, largely in company shares. This substantial pay package is being compared to Tesla CEO Elon Musk's compensation, which also primarily consisted of stock options. QuantumScape is developing advanced solid-state lithium-metal batteries for electric vehicles, with promising performance metrics such as fast charging and high energy density.

title: Made in New Zealand - Model Y
summary: A Tesla Model Y owner questions why their VIN starts with '7,' typically indicating New Zealand as the country of origin, sparking a discussion among forum members about VIN country codes and Tesla's manufacturing locations. It is revealed that recent Model Y VINs starting with '7SA' no longer solely denote New Zealand but are a new manufacturer code assigned by Tesla since November 2021 for certain models, overriding traditional VIN interpretations. The discussion also touches on enthusiasts' desire for vehicles from new factories offering cutting-edge technology like single-piece rear castings and 4680 batteries.

title: Tesla faces investor lawsuit over Musk tweets on 10% stock sales
summary: Tesla is facing an investor lawsuit over CEO Elon Musk's social media posts, specifically a Twitter poll regarding stock sales that led to a significant drop in its stock prices. The lawsuit seeks access to internal documents to determine if Tesla and Musk violated a 2018 agreement with the U.S. securities regulator, which required company lawyers to pre-approve tweets with material information. This legal action follows a substantial decrease in Tesla shares after Musk proposed selling 10% of his stake.

title: Governor Kemp Welcomes Rivian for Single-Largest Economic Development Project in State History
summary: Governor Brian P. Kemp announced that Rivian Inc. will invest $5 billion to build an electric adventure vehicle manufacturing plant in Georgia, creating approximately 7,500 jobs. This project, located at the East Atlanta Megasite, represents the single-largest economic development project in the state's history and aims to produce up to 400,000 vehicles annually. The facility, set to begin production in 2024, will also support Rivian's research and development programs and contribute to the expansion of the U.S. electric vehicle industry.

title: TeraWulf Is Attracting A-List Investors For Its Sustainable Bitcoin Solution
summary: TeraWulf, a company focused on environmentally-friendly Bitcoin mining, is attracting A-list investors due to its sustainable approach. Notable investors like Gwyneth Paltrow, Mindy Kaling, and Sara Foster have joined, supporting TeraWulf's goal of achieving 100% zero-carbon emissions in its operations by leveraging nuclear, hydro, and solar power. The company aims to address environmental concerns associated with cryptocurrency mining and is preparing for a public debut to expand its substantial mining capacity.

title: GM CEO says making ventilators at Indiana factory changed the company culture
summary: GM CEO Mary Barra states that making ventilators at an Indiana factory during the COVID-19 pandemic significantly changed the company's culture, giving them confidence to accelerate other tasks like electric vehicle development. The experience also influenced GM's approach to securing raw materials for EV production as they transition away from internal combustion engines. Barra also hinted at a potential EV battery factory in Michigan and commented on GM's stock valuation compared to Tesla.

title: How ConocoPhillips is opening an innovation treasure trove
summary: ConocoPhillips is fostering a culture of innovation, led by Director Liz Jolley, to drive success and adapt to a changing industry. The company utilizes its "Fuel" software platform to facilitate global collaboration, allowing employees to share ideas and adopt proven solutions. This approach has led to significant improvements in operations, cost reduction, and problem-solving across various business units worldwide.

title: General Motors returns to rare earth magnets with two U.S. deals
summary: General Motors announced two deals to source rare earth magnets for its electric vehicles from new U.S.-based manufacturing facilities, marking a return to an industry it had largely abandoned. These agreements with MP Materials Inc. and Vacuumschmelze aim to domestically source EV materials for GM's Ultium platform by 2025, aligning with the Biden administration's push for U.S. EV supply chain investments. The move seeks to reduce reliance on China, which currently dominates rare earth production and magnet manufacturing.

title: Ford Motor Co. beefs up tech strength with director known for global dominance
summary: Ford Motor Co. has elected John May, CEO of Deere & Co., to its board of directors, a move analysts say underscores Ford's commitment to technology and dominance in electric and autonomous vehicles. May's experience with Deere's technologically advanced agricultural equipment and successful resolution of a recent UAW strike are seen as valuable assets for Ford's own transformation and supply chain management. The appointment expands Ford's board to 15 members, though some observers noted the company's lack of progress in increasing female board representation compared to competitors like GM.

title: Deere & Co. CEO tapped to serve on Ford's board of directors
summary: Ford Motor Co. announced a leadership reshuffling, including the appointment of John C. May, CEO of Deere & Co., to its board of directors. May's experience in transforming Deere into a "smart industrial company" with a focus on technology is seen as valuable to Ford's own technology-driven initiatives. Additionally, the automaker announced the retirement of Mitch Bainwol, chief government relations officer, effective December 31.

title: What's Inside the 4 Largest Clean Energy ETFs
summary: This article examines the four largest clean energy ETFs in the United States, highlighting the diverse approaches their underlying indexes take to define clean energy and select stocks. It details how "clean energy" definitions vary, leading to different portfolio compositions, and reveals that many clean energy funds still have significant fossil-fuel exposure. The piece also notes that these funds often exhibit higher correlations to the technology sector than to traditional energy benchmarks.

title: Intel plans to take self-driving car unit public in the U.S. in mid-2022
summary: Intel announced its plan to take its self-driving car unit, Mobileye, public in the U.S. in mid-2022 through an IPO. Intel acquired Mobileye for $15.3 billion in 2017, and the IPO is expected to value Mobileye at over $50 billion, creating value for Intel shareholders who will remain majority owners. This move aims to give Mobileye more visibility and help fund Intel's expansion plans, including building new chip plants.

title: Exclusive: SEC probes Tesla over whistleblower claims on solar panel defects
summary: The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission has initiated an investigation into Tesla Inc. regarding a whistleblower complaint that the company failed to inform shareholders and the public about fire risks associated with solar panel system defects. The probe follows a complaint from a former Tesla field quality manager, Steven Henkes, who alleged that Tesla and SolarCity concealed "liability and exposure to property damage, risk of injury of users, fire etc to shareholders." Tesla's shares fell significantly following the Reuters report.

title: Ford aims to be world's #2 electric vehicle maker within two years - COO
summary: Ford Motor Co. expects to become the world's second-largest electric vehicle manufacturer within two years, targeting an annual production capacity of nearly 600,000 EVs. This ambition is fueled by strong demand for its F-150 Lightning pickup and plans for greater vertical integration of EV components and battery production. Ford is also developing various battery technologies with multiple global suppliers to reduce costs.

title: Why Biden won’t talk about Tesla
summary: President Biden rarely mentions Tesla Inc. and Elon Musk, an omission analysts link to the administration's pro-union stance and Tesla's anti-union policies. Biden frequently praises traditional automakers like Ford and General Motors for their EV initiatives, while conspicuously excluding Tesla from events and discussions despite its leading role in electric vehicle production. This snub has intensified scrutiny from Tesla fans and Musk himself, highlighting a divide between the administration's labor focus and the tech-bro ethos associated with Tesla.

title: Solar ETF Is Credible Avenue to Battery Storage Boom
summary: The article highlights the Invesco Solar ETF (TAN) as a compelling investment avenue for the burgeoning battery storage market. It explains that several solar companies within TAN's holdings are making significant advancements in battery storage, which Goldman Sachs projects will see substantial growth over the next decade. Major components of TAN, Enphase Energy (ENPH) and SolarEdge Technologies (SDGE), are identified as key beneficiaries of this trend.

title: SCE Quadruples Rebate Offer for Pre-Owned EVs
summary: Southern California Edison (SCE) has quadrupled its rebate for income-qualified customers purchasing or leasing pre-owned electric vehicles, increasing it from $1,000 to $4,000. This initiative aims to make clean transportation more accessible and affordable, particularly for those in income-qualified households or on state/federal assistance programs, thereby stimulating EV adoption to help California meet its climate goals. The rebate program is available to the first, second, and third owners or lessors of pre-owned EVs, and customers can apply online.

title: Tesla officially moves headquarters to site of new Austin factory
summary: Tesla has officially moved its corporate headquarters from Palo Alto, California, to Austin, Texas, to the same site where it is building its new $1.1 billion manufacturing facility. Documents filed with the SEC confirmed the relocation to 13101 Harold Green Road in Austin. This move follows CEO Elon Musk's announcement in October and reflects the company's growth limitations in the San Francisco Bay Area and the increasing presence of Musk's other ventures in Central Texas.

title: The FAANG Market Is Fading
summary: The article discusses the fading hyper-concentration of stock market returns from a handful of large technology stocks, particularly the FAANGs, in 2021 compared to 2020. This shift suggests a healthier market dynamic with less risk for index funds and more opportunities for stock-pickers. While large stocks still contribute significantly, their overall impact on market returns has decreased, resembling a more traditional market distribution.

title: Apple loses a top vehicle engineer to flying-taxi startup Archer Aviation
summary: Michael Schwekutsch, a top vehicle engineer previously with Apple's "Project Titan" electric vehicle initiative, has joined Archer Aviation, a startup focused on building flying taxis. His departure comes as Apple tries to accelerate its self-driving car project, sparking discussions among analysts about Apple Car's potential impact on the broader EV market, particularly on Tesla.

title: ACES Covers Battery Bases
summary: The article highlights the ALPS Clean Energy ETF (ACES) for its broad exposure to the renewable energy ecosystem, particularly its significant allocation to electric vehicle and energy storage companies. It emphasizes the critical role of battery storage in future growth, citing Goldman Sachs' projections for substantial market expansion. Key holdings like Tesla, Enphase Energy, and Stem underscore ACES' focus on leading players in the battery storage sector.

title: Firms beef up retirement benefits to attract and retain employees
summary: Firms are enhancing retirement benefits to attract and retain employees, as highlighted by KPMG's more generous match being a key differentiator. The article also touches on related topics such as the SEC's delayed work on private credit in 401(k) plans due to government shutdown, investment strategies of university endowments, private equity AUM growth, and CalPERS' voting stance on executive pay packages.

title: Global X Blockchain ETF Up Nearly 50% YTD
summary: The Global X Blockchain ETF (BKCH) has seen significant growth in 2021, rising nearly 50% year-to-date due to the rally in cryptocurrencies and increasing interest in blockchain technology. The ETF provides exposure to companies involved in blockchain, such as Marathon Digital Holdings and Coinbase, and is poised to benefit from the global expansion and adoption of blockchain in various sectors. Looking ahead to 2022, trends like increased business investment and a focus on "greenifying" blockchain are expected to further drive the sector's growth.

title: Ford, GM Step Into Chip Business
summary: Detroit's two largest car companies, Ford and General Motors, are venturing into the semiconductor business in response to the ongoing global chip shortage that has hampered their production. Ford has signed a strategic agreement with GlobalFoundries Inc. to develop chips, potentially leading to joint U.S. production. This move reflects a broader reevaluation of the automotive supply chain by manufacturers.

title: Best Funds in Fidelity's Sweet Spot
summary: This article identifies five top-performing large-growth funds from Fidelity's extensive lineup, highlighting their management styles and investment strategies. It distinguishes between "style-pure" and "wide-ranging growth" funds, discussing how experienced managers and their approaches contribute to the funds' success despite varying market conditions and asset bases. The piece provides a guide for investors navigating Fidelity's growth-oriented offerings.

title: Global X signals intent in Europe with seven thematic ETF launches
summary: Global X has launched seven new thematic ETFs in Europe, expanding its UCITS range to 12 products. These ETFs cover various themes including autonomous vehicles, clean tech, cybersecurity, e-commerce, fintech, IoT, and robotics/AI, with TERs ranging from 0.50% to 0.60%. This move signifies Global X's robust growth and commitment to offering targeted exposure to disruptive global themes for European investors.

title: Stock of the week - Rivian Automotive (18.11.2021)
summary: Rivian Automotive, the US electric vehicles manufacturer, had its IPO on November 10th, with shares gaining 120% in the first 5 days before dropping 15%. Despite $0 revenue, the company achieved a significant market cap, briefly becoming the third largest automaker. Comparisons are drawn between Rivian's cash burn and early Tesla, with Rivian burning cash at a faster rate but benefiting from a massive order from Amazon.

title: Focus: With limited EV options, Uber embraces carbon offsets in Latin America
summary: Uber, aiming for carbon neutrality by 2040, is utilizing carbon offsets in parts of Latin America due to the impracticality of transitioning drivers to electric vehicles in nascent EV markets. This strategy is controversial and raises questions about the genuine impact of the offset projects Uber supports. The company faces challenges in these emerging markets with limited sustainable alternatives, despite plans to encourage EV adoption.

title: Taking Charge: Mary Powell on her new gig at Sunrun and the importance of ‘radical collaboration’
summary: Mary Powell discusses her new role as CEO of Sunrun and emphasizes the need for "radical collaboration" to accelerate the energy transition and combat climate change. She highlights lessons from her previous role at Green Mountain Power, focusing on the scalability of distributed energy resources and the cultural shift required from utilities to view these resources as opportunities rather than threats. Powell expresses optimism about the future, noting that existing technologies are sufficient and that the industry is approaching a tipping point for clean energy.

title: JPMorgan sues Tesla for $162 mln after Musk tweets soured warrant deal
summary: JPMorgan Chase & Co is suing Tesla Inc for $162.2 million, alleging breach of contract related to warrants Tesla sold to the bank in 2014. The dispute stems from JPMorgan's re-pricing of these warrants following Elon Musk's 2018 tweets about taking Tesla private, which created significant stock volatility. JPMorgan claims Tesla failed to honor its contractual obligations to pay after the warrants expired and Tesla's stock price surged.

title: Crypto Mining for Digital Gold is Going Green
summary: The article discusses the environmental concerns surrounding cryptocurrency mining, particularly Bitcoin, and highlights efforts within the industry to adopt renewable energy sources. It addresses misconceptions about electricity consumption, comparing it to other industries and countries, and details initiatives like the Crypto Climate Accord aimed at decarbonizing the sector. The piece concludes that while environmental sustainability standards are still evolving, crypto mining companies are progressing towards greener operations.

title: Hedge Fund and Insider Trading News: Cliff Asness, Bill Ackman, Dan Sundheim, Viking Global Investors, Engine No. 1, Commscope Holding Company Inc (COMM), Tesla Inc (TSLA), and More
summary: This article covers recent activities and news involving prominent hedge fund managers and companies. It discusses AQR Capital Management's resource cuts, Bill Ackman's penthouse project, D1 Capital and Viking Global's significant investments in Peloton, Melvin Capital's portfolio shake-up, and Elon Musk's response to Tesla critic Michael Burry.

title: New VinFast VF e35 electric SUV revealed as Tesla Model Y rival
summary: Vietnamese brand VinFast is set to debut its new VF e35 electric SUV at the LA Auto Show, targeting rivals like the Volkswagen ID.4 and Tesla Model Y. Designed by Pininfarina, the VF e35 will offer a range of up to 250 miles and level 3 autonomous driving capabilities, with deliveries expected to begin next year. The vehicle aims to be competitively priced in Western markets.

title: JPMorgan files $162 million lawsuit against Tesla over warrants, citing Musk tweet
summary: JPMorgan Chase has filed a $162 million lawsuit against Tesla, alleging breach of contract over stock warrants. The lawsuit stems from Elon Musk's 2018 tweet about taking Tesla private at $420, which JPMorgan claims significantly decreased the value of the warrants. JPMorgan asserts Tesla flagrantly ignored its contractual obligation to pay when the warrants expired.

title: Conductive carbon additives: energise the future
summary: Cabot Corporation's Senior Business Development Manager, Paolina Atanassova, discusses how their extensive range of conductive carbon additives is supporting lithium-ion battery applications. The article highlights Cabot's commitment to sustainability and innovation in battery materials, including their LITX Carbon Black and ENERMAX™ carbon nanotubes, to meet the growing demands of the automotive and energy storage industries. It also touches upon their R&D commitment and collaborative efforts to develop next-generation battery technologies.

title: Hedge Fund and Insider Trading News: Kyle Bass, Ken Griffin, Elliott Management, Soros Fund Management, Sachem Head Capital Management, Renaissance Technologies, Regional Management Corp. (RM), Aon PLC (AON), and More
summary: This article covers recent hedge fund activities, including Renaissance Technologies quadrupling its Tesla stake and boosting its AMC bet, Kyle Bass's skepticism about Bitcoin's future due to regulation, and Soros Fund Management's increased investments in real estate and financial stocks. It also details Elliott Management securing board seats at Duke Energy and Sachem Head Capital Management's strong performance.

title: Tesla dips after Musk sheds $5 billion in shares
summary: Tesla's stock dipped slightly after CEO Elon Musk sold approximately $5 billion worth of his shares, following a Twitter poll about offloading 10% of his stake. This sale, his first since 2016, included shares sold to cover tax obligations after exercising options and comes amid proposals for taxing billionaires' stock holdings. Despite the sale, analysts believe it won't negatively impact long-term investors, as Musk's compensation is largely stock-based.

title: 26-Year-Old CEO Takes His Autonomous Truck Company Public in $5 Billion Deal
summary: Embark Trucks, led by 26-year-old CEO Alex Rodrigues, has gone public on the Nasdaq under the ticker EMBK in a $5 billion deal. Rodrigues is now one of the youngest heads of an autonomous-driving company to navigate the public market. The initial market reception was cool, with shares falling as much as 7.3% in the first minute of trading.

title: 26-Year-Old Alex Rodrigues Becomes Youngest Current CEO Of A Publicly Traded Company With $5 Billion Embark SPAC Merger
summary: Alex Rodrigues, at 26, has become the youngest current CEO of a publicly traded company after his autonomous trucking software company, Embark, went public via a $5 billion SPAC merger. Rodrigues, who developed a self-driving golf cart at 19, founded Embark to focus on 18-wheelers, aiming to revolutionize the trucking industry. He is estimated to be worth $500 million and lives a minimalist lifestyle, focused on growing Embark, which aims to fulfill over 14,200 reservations for Embark-enabled trucks by 2024.

title: Rivian valued at over $100 bln in debut, after world's biggest IPO of 2021
authors: Noor Zainab Hussain and Ben Klayman
summary: Rivian Automotive Inc surged over 50% in its Nasdaq debut, reaching a market valuation exceeding $100 billion after the world's largest IPO of 2021, and becoming the second most valuable U.S. automaker after Tesla. Despite limited revenue, the Amazon-backed EV maker is investing heavily in production and plans to expand globally, with its CEO emphasizing growth into new segments and vehicles. General Motors' CEO noted that Rivian's valuation highlighted her company's undervaluation.

title: Hertz Relists on NASDAQ Global Select Market as HTZ
summary: Hertz Global Holdings Inc. has relisted its shares on the Nasdaq Global Select Market under the ticker HTZ, following its emergence from bankruptcy earlier this year. Shareholder sold 44.5 million shares in an upsized public offering, though Hertz itself did not receive proceeds and plans to repurchase $300 million worth of shares. The company is also focusing on electric vehicles, with plans to acquire 100,000 Teslas and rent 50,000 EVs to Uber.

title: Investors Can Now Short ARK Invest via SARK ETF
summary: The Tuttle Capital Short Innovation ETF (SARK) has launched, allowing investors to bet against Cathie Wood's ARK Innovation ETF (ARKK). SARK is an actively managed inverse ETF, rebalanced daily, offering a way for more speculative investors to short ARKK without the direct risks of individual short selling. This new ETF caters to those who believe the bull thesis for transformational industries might be stretched or wish to hedge existing high-growth portfolios.

title: Amazon And Other Big Winners In Rivian’s Supercharged IPO
summary: Rivian's anticipated IPO is set to be the largest of 2021, showcasing significant investor confidence in the electric vehicle market despite Rivian being largely pre-revenue. Major stakeholders like Amazon, T. Rowe Price, Global Oryx Company Ltd., Ford Motor Co., and Manheim Investments are poised for substantial financial gains from the public offering. Their investments, primarily made in the past few years, reflect a strong bet on the future of electric transportation.

title: 3 Solid Climate Tech Funds for Investors
summary: The article discusses the burgeoning climate tech investment sector, highlighting the volatility and concentration of publicly traded companies in the space. It recommends three funds—GMO Climate Change III, New Alternatives, and SPDR Kensho Clean Power ETF—for investors interested in climate technology, advising caution and diversification due to the sector's risks.
