summary: The article discusses the advancements and applications of blue lasers for welding copper, a critical material in electric vehicles and electronics. It highlights how blue lasers overcome the limitations of traditional infrared lasers by providing rapid, high-quality, and defect-free welds for various geometries and materials due to copper's higher absorption of blue light. The technology's increased brightness and integration with industry-standard scanning systems enable its use in automated production lines, offering significant improvements in speed, quality, and efficiency.

title: ‘Mysterious’ billionaire cashes in $127M worth of Gates-backed pharma stock
summary: David Shaw, a "mysterious" billionaire, has sold over $127 million worth of Schrödinger, Inc. (SDGR) stock, a company backed by Bill Gates. Schrödinger, Inc. has seen its stock rise significantly since its IPO, attracting attention due to the substantial holdings of both Shaw and Gates, who together own around 40% of the company. This article details Shaw's recent stock sales and highlights the significant influence both billionaires have on the high-tech drug discovery firm.

title: General Motors finally gets serious about in-car tech, taps Unreal Engine for next-gen interface
summary: General Motors is set to significantly upgrade its in-car technology by integrating Epic Games' Unreal Engine into the upcoming GMC Hummer EV. This move aims to deliver a more dynamic and robust user experience, addressing previous criticisms of GM's infotainment systems. The adoption of Unreal Engine, known for powering advanced video games, signals a serious push by GM to improve its digital offerings and compete with electric vehicle rivals like Tesla.

title: Tesla could still hit 500,000-vehicle target this year, Musk says
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk informed employees via an internal email that the company still has a chance to produce 500,000 vehicles this year, despite challenges, emphasizing the critical role of the fourth quarter. To achieve this ambitious target, Tesla will need to deliver nearly 182,000 vehicles in the fourth quarter, building on its record 139,300 deliveries in the third quarter. The company's Shanghai factory is contributing significantly to this production push.

title: Tesla to Acquire Builder of Battery Assembly Lines
summary: Tesla Inc. is set to acquire ATW Automation, a German company specializing in building battery and transmission assembly lines for major automakers. This acquisition comes as Tesla plans to significantly ramp up its battery production and reduce costs, coinciding with its construction of new vehicle manufacturing facilities that will include battery plants. ATW Automation, a subsidiary of ATS Automation Tooling Systems Inc., was facing liquidation due to decreased orders.

title: Elon Musk’s Tesla reports blowout third quarter sales
summary: Tesla reported a 44 percent jump in third-quarter sales, delivering 139,000 vehicles, surpassing Wall Street's optimistic projections. This strong performance positions the company to potentially hit 500,000 unit sales for the year despite pandemic-related factory closures. The news, however, did not boost share prices immediately, with Tesla's stock falling 5 percent amidst a broader market sell-off driven by President Trump's COVID-19 diagnosis, though shares remain up significantly for the year.

title: Impact of Tesla Battery on this ARK ETF
summary: Tesla's Battery Day revealed plans for $25,000 cars within three years, a 56% battery cost reduction, and increased output, which has positive implications for the ARK Autonomous Technology & Robotics ETF (ARKQ). ARK Invest believes Tesla's innovations, driven by vertical integration, confirm its Wright's Law analysis for battery cost declines, positioning the company even further ahead of competitors. Tesla's focus on dollars per range and vehicle performance, rather than just $/kWh, is seen as a key differentiator.

title: About 3,500 US Companies Sue Over Trump-Imposed Chinese Tariffs
summary: Around 3,500 U.S. companies, including major firms like Tesla, Ford, and Target, have filed lawsuits against the Trump administration for imposing tariffs on over $300 billion in Chinese goods. These lawsuits allege that the administration failed to impose tariffs within the required 12-month period and did not comply with administrative procedures, challenging the "unbounded and unlimited trade war" with China. This legal action comes after the World Trade Organization found the U.S. breached global trading rules with its tariffs against China.
source: VOA - Voice of America English News
source_domain: VOA - Voice of America English News

title: Ford Reveals Blisteringly Quick Mustang Mach-E GT for Europe: Nothing in its Class Accelerates Faster
summary: Ford unveils the high-performance Mustang Mach-E GT for the European market, boasting 0-100 km/h acceleration in 3.7 seconds, making it the fastest accelerating vehicle in its class. The article highlights Ford's commitment to electrification, including free access to charging networks and the European debut of the Mustang Mach-E 1400 prototype. Ford is expanding its range of electrified models and calls for greater investment in public charging infrastructure.

title: Letter to Tesla: Respect Indigenous Peoples in Your Supply Chain
summary: A coalition of Indigenous Peoples, environmental, and human rights organizations sent a letter to Tesla urging them not to partner with nickel producer Nornickel due to its extensive record of human rights violations and environmental damage in the Arctic, impacting various Indigenous communities. The organizations commend Tesla's commitment to sustainability but emphasize that Nornickel's practices are inconsistent with these values and call on Tesla to refuse to buy from Nornickel until it complies with environmental and human rights standards. The article includes a timeline of related events and actions taken by NGOs regarding Nornickel and Tesla.

title: Brandon Lopez Obituary - Pueblo, CO
summary: This obituary details the life of Brandon Christopher Lopez, who passed away on September 22, 2020, at the age of 29 in Pueblo, Colorado. Born in Bad Nauheim, Germany, Brandon was a decorated veteran of the United States Air Force and an engineer for CACI International Inc. The article highlights his love for technology, family, and travel, as well as his academic and athletic achievements.

title: Baidu-backed Chinese EV startup WM Motor raises $1.5 bln
summary: Baidu-backed Chinese electric vehicle (EV) startup WM Motor has raised 10 billion yuan ($1.47 billion) in its latest funding round, aiming to further develop intelligent vehicle technologies and expand sales channels. The funding comes as EV makers experience a surge in stock prices and intense market interest. WM Motor is also reportedly preparing for a STAR board listing.

title: Amazon (AMZN) Investing In Battery Recycling Company Redwood Materials
summary: Amazon (NASDAQ: AMZN) is investing in Redwood Materials, a battery recycling startup founded by former Tesla executive JB Straubel, as part of Amazon's Climate Pledge Fund. The investment aims to enhance sustainability by recycling batteries from Amazon's diverse operations, including Amazon Web Services, consumer electronics, and its growing electric logistics fleet. Redwood Materials will specifically focus on recycling batteries for electric vehicles and lithium-ion batteries.

title: Will GM’s Ultium Drive be the small-block V-8 for a generation of EVs?
summary: General Motors announced "Ultium Drive" as the branding for key components in its upcoming electric vehicles, encompassing power electronics, motors, and single-speed transmissions. This strategy mirrors GM's historical success with its small-block V-8 and aims to achieve economies of scale through interchangeable drive units and motors, enabling a wide range of power outputs and vehicle layouts from 235 hp to 1,000 hp. GM expects these integrated drive units to offer industry-leading torque and power density, with manufacturing largely handled by existing global propulsion facilities using globally sourced parts.

title: Why Investors Should Not Expect a NextEra Stock Split to Act Like Apple or Tesla
summary: NextEra Energy Inc. announced a 4-for-1 stock split and increased its financial expectations for 2021, 2022, and 2023. While stock splits often generate excitement, investors are cautioned not to expect a similar stock surge seen with Apple and Tesla, as NextEra is a utility stock with different market dynamics. Despite being the largest U.S. utility by market cap and a strong performer, its P/E ratios and low dividend yield reflect a different investment profile.

title: A new electric-truck stock is hitting the market
summary: Electric truck company Hyliion is set to go public through a merger with special purpose acquisition company Tortoise Acquisition Corp., with shareholders voting on the deal on September 28. Hyliion, which offers hybrid and fully electric powertrain solutions for commercial vehicles, will trade on the NYSE under the ticker HYLN and expects to accelerate product commercialization with $560 million from the merger. The move comes amid significant investor interest in electric vehicle companies and SPAC mergers, with shares of Tortoise Acquisition already up over 400% since the merger announcement.

title: Top 5 Vendors in the Automotive Camera Module Market - COVID Impact | Technavio
summary: Technavio's latest report on the Global Automotive Camera Module Market predicts negative and inferior growth due to COVID-19, with 33% of the market growth anticipated from Europe. The market is driven by the steady growth of the ADAS market and increased popularity of CMOS sensors. The report identifies key vendors like Autoliv Inc., Continental AG, and LG Innotek, highlighting their offerings in vision systems and camera modules for ADAS and autonomous driving.

title: GM takes a $2 billion stake in Nikola to make electric pickup trucks
summary: General Motors is taking a $2 billion stake in electric vehicle maker Nikola Corp. in a deal expected to benefit GM by $4 billion as it commercializes its EV technology. This 10-year partnership aims to reduce costs for both companies and facilitate GM's all-electric vehicle strategy, with GM engineering and manufacturing Nikola's Badger electric pickup and other vehicles. The move strengthens GM's position in the EV market, provides scale for its Ultium battery and Hydrotec fuel cell systems, and positions Nikola to compete with other EV manufacturers.

title: GM acquires stake in electric truck maker Nikola, will help make the company’s first vehicle
summary: General Motors has acquired an 11 percent stake in electric truck startup Nikola, a deal that includes GM assisting Nikola in engineering and manufacturing its battery-electric and hydrogen fuel cell vehicles, such as the Badger pickup truck. Nikola will exchange $2 billion in common stock for GM's in-kind services and access to its parts and components. Nikola will remain an independent company, responsible for sales and marketing of the Badger, with production expected to start in late 2022.

title: Honda and General Motors Sign MoU Toward Establishing a Strategic Alliance in North America
summary: General Motors and Honda signed a non-binding memorandum of understanding to form a strategic automotive alliance in North America. This collaboration aims to share vehicle platforms, propulsion systems, and co-develop technologies, building on their existing partnership in electric vehicles and autonomous technology. The alliance seeks to achieve significant cost efficiencies, accelerate innovation, and optimize resource deployment for both companies.

title: WorkSport Introduces TerraVis: World's First Solar Panel Tonneau Cover
summary: Worksport has introduced TerraVis, a solar-powered generator system that doubles as a tonneau cover for pickup trucks. While it can charge electric and plug-in hybrid truck batteries, its primary use is for portable on-demand power in conventional trucks, for job sites, remote adventures, or emergency power during outages. The modular system features monocrystalline solar panels, a battery system (up to four 2 kWh packs plus a 1 kWh portable pack), and an inverter, with Worksport also in negotiations to offer it as a factory option for electric pickup manufacturers.

title: Apple and Tesla shares spike after stock splits kick in
summary: Apple and Tesla shares surged on Monday after their stock splits took effect, attracting significant investor buying. Apple jumped over 4 percent after its 4-for-1 split, while Tesla rallied 10 percent following its 5-for-1 split, elevating its market capitalization to over $440 billion and showcasing the impact of increased affordability for individual investors. The success of these splits may encourage other companies with high-priced stocks to consider similar moves, as both Silicon Valley companies have strong individual investor followings.

title: Nio raises size of share sale to capitalize on red-hot demand for electric-vehicle stocks
summary: Nio, a Chinese electric-vehicle maker and Tesla rival, increased the size of its stock offering, raising $1.5 billion, to capitalize on strong investor demand for EV stocks. The proceeds will be used to enhance Nio's ownership in Nio China, fund autonomous driving R&D, and for general corporate purposes. This move follows a period of significant gains for EV stocks, including Tesla and Xpeng.

title: Soon, the Kitty Litter Will Come by Electric Truck (Published 2020)
summary: Major delivery carriers like UPS, FedEx, and Amazon are intensifying their efforts to electrify their vehicle fleets in response to surging delivery demand during the pandemic. This push is driven by concerns about climate change, rising delivery costs, government regulations, and significant advancements in battery technology, which are making electric vehicles more cost-effective. Industry analysts predict a substantial increase in electric delivery van orders as the economics of EVs become more favorable than diesel for short, local delivery operations.

title: China's Xpeng surges 67% on U.S. debut, raises $1.5 billion in IPO
summary: Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker Xpeng Inc saw its shares surge as much as 67% on its U.S. market debut, raising $1.5 billion in an IPO. The successful listing marks a significant year for IPOs, particularly for companies focused on cleaner technology, and follows similar surges in other EV makers. Xpeng plans to use the funds for R&D and sales expansion, targeting the mass-market segment in China.

title: China's Xpeng IPO raises $1.5 billion in U.S. IPO for smart EV technologies, expansion
summary: Chinese EV maker Xpeng has increased its U.S. IPO to $1.5 billion, raising more than a third above its initial target, driven by strong investor interest in clean technology companies. The company plans to use the funds for research and development and sales expansion, focusing on a mass-market segment in China with cars priced between 150,000 to 300,000 yuan. This IPO marks the third major New York listing by a Chinese EV company in two years, amidst surging share prices for EV manufacturers like Tesla and Nio.

title: Electric vehicle chassis provider Motiv announces fresh funding
summary: Motiv Power Systems secured an additional $15 million in funding from GMAG Holdings Corp, bringing its total capital raised to $95 million. This funding will support technology development and scaling manufacturing operations for its electric vehicle chassis and software systems for medium-duty trucks and buses. The company's efforts align with the growing demand for electric commercial vehicles, spurred by regulations like California's zero-emission vehicle mandate.

title: Land Rover Defender Gets Tesla Power and up to 600 hp
summary: E.C.D. Automotive Design and Electric Classic Cars have teamed up to offer classic Land Rover Defenders with Tesla powertrains, delivering up to 600 hp and a range of 125-250 miles. Buyers can choose between 450 hp and 600 hp versions, with the 450-hp model achieving 0 to 60 mph in 5.5 seconds. The companies plan to make these electric Defenders 50-state compliant and offer extensive customization, with future plans to extend the electric drivetrain to classic Range Rover models and Series Land Rovers.

title: Tesla at $2,000: Electric car maker’s stock extends its surge
summary: Tesla's shares surged past $2,000 for the first time, reaching a record high of $2,001.83, ahead of a five-for-one stock split. The company's stock has risen over 300 percent in 2020, with investors betting on its addition to the S&P 500 index. Despite high valuation concerns, Tesla continues to outperform rivals and is set to roll out "made-in-China" Model Y vehicles and announce battery innovations.

title: The Inside Story Of Robinhood’s Billionaire Founders, Option Kid Cowboys And The Wall Street Sharks That Feed On Them
summary: This article delves into Robinhood's rapid rise, driven by commission-free trading and a surge of novice investors during the pandemic, and reveals its controversial business model of selling customer order flow to high-frequency trading firms. It explores how this model, while minting billionaire founders, prioritizes profit from sophisticated market makers, potentially at the expense of inexperienced traders. The piece also highlights the platform's challenges, including outages and the tragic death of a user, leading to calls for better regulation and education.

title: Can General Motors Release Its Inner Tesla?
summary: This article discusses the challenge General Motors faces in the electric vehicle market, where Tesla's market value continues to surge despite minimal clear causes. While financial maneuvers might help GM secure cheaper capital, they are unlikely to significantly boost its market value to Tesla's levels, indicating a disparity in investor perception between pure EV companies and traditional automakers venturing into EVs.

title: Xos Trucks Secures $20 Million in New Funding Round
summary: Xos Trucks Inc., an electric vehicle developer, has successfully raised $20 million in a new funding round from investors including Proeza Ventures and BUILD Capital Group. The funding will be used to scale the production of its X-Platform chassis system, which is currently being piloted by Loomis and tested by UPS Inc. Xos aims to meet the increasing demand for reliable, affordable, and sustainable transportation solutions, especially with the surge in e-commerce.

title: Gold Diggers; Nvidia ARMed; TSLA’s Chinese Bevy; Sorry Chevy
summary: This article discusses the current market trends in gold, Nvidia, Tesla, and General Motors. It highlights gold's rallying price despite being considered a "boring" investment, Nvidia's potential acquisition of ARM Holdings, Tesla's fluctuating registration numbers in China despite a rising stock price, and General Motors' reluctance to fully embrace the EV market. The article also provides a rundown of upcoming earnings reports in the retail and semiconductor sectors.

title: Departure of GM CFO Dhivya Suryadevara highlights ongoing 'brain drain' problem for auto industry
summary: The departure of GM CFO Dhivya Suryadevara to digital payments company Stripe highlights a growing "brain drain" problem for traditional automakers like GM and Ford. As the automotive and tech sectors increasingly collide, these companies struggle with talent acquisition and retention, losing seasoned executives and promising mid-career professionals to tech firms and startups. This trend is exacerbated by a perceived lack of appeal in the automotive industry compared to the innovative allure of the tech sector.

title: Tesla to Enact 5-for-1 Stock Split
summary: Tesla Inc. announced a 5-for-1 stock split following a significant surge in its share price, which has made it the most valuable car company. This move comes after four consecutive quarters of profit and expectations of its first-ever full-year profit. Tesla's shares increased by over 6% in after-hours trading after the announcement.

title: Meet ‘China’s Elon Musk’ Li Xiang, founder of recently US-listed EV maker Li Auto
summary: The article profiles Li Xiang, the founder of US-listed EV maker Li Auto, often called 'China's Elon Musk'. It details his journey as a serial entrepreneur, including previous ventures like Autohome, and the challenges faced in establishing Li Auto, which specializes in extended-range electric vehicles. Despite setbacks and intense market competition, Li Auto achieved a successful IPO, with Li Xiang maintaining significant control and aiming for the company to be one of the top three EV players in China.

title: Tesla, electric cars help Silicon Labs weather Covid-19 crisis
summary: Austin-based fabless semiconductor company Silicon Labs anticipates continued growth supported by its electric vehicle manufacturer customers, including Tesla. Despite the downturn, the company's workforce has remained stable, and its CEO and CFO discussed new technology and the global operations of the company.

title: The world’s hottest stock is a money-losing tech giant soaring 880%
summary: Sea Ltd., a Singapore-based tech company involved in gaming, e-commerce, and payments, has become the world's best-performing large-cap stock, soaring over 880% in 18 months despite being loss-making. This surge has sparked debate about whether it's a future internet giant or an example of a tech bubble. CEO Forrest Li is focusing on expansion through mobile games, online shopping, and financial services, with significant backing from investors like Tencent and Tiger Global Management.

title: Ford CEO Jim Hackett to retire; Chief Operating Officer Jim Farley will take helm
summary: Ford Motor Co. CEO Jim Hackett is retiring from his position, effective October 1, 2020, and will be succeeded by Chief Operating Officer Jim Farley. Hackett led the company since May 2017, overseeing a restructuring plan and challenges with product launches and stock value, while Farley is known as a "car guy" with a strong background in the auto industry and a focus on flawless product execution and an expanded affordable lineup. The transition comes as Ford faces intense competition and an evolving industry landscape, with many analysts and employees expressing optimism about Farley's leadership.

title: Ford Motor Company gets new CEO on October 1st
summary: Jim Hackett is retiring as CEO of Ford Motor Company after three years, with current Chief Operating Officer Jim Farley taking over on October 1st, 2020. Farley aims for a 10% operating margin and acknowledges new competitors like Amazon, Baidu, Tesla, and Apple. He also faces the challenge of reviving Ford's declining car sales in China and navigating the company through the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.

title: How the U.S. IPO of a Chinese electric vehicle maker defied Washington’s roadblocks
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker Li Auto successfully raised $1.1 billion in an IPO on Nasdaq, valuing the company at around $10 billion, despite increased scrutiny on Chinese stocks in the U.S. The company specializes in extended-range electric vehicles and its shares surged 43% on its first day of trading. This IPO comes amidst potential U.S. legislation aiming to delist foreign firms that do not comply with audit inspections, an issue Li Auto acknowledges in its SEC filing.

title: GM fast-charging investment will fuel EVgo network expansion, charge future EVs
summary: General Motors and EVgo announced a partnership to install over 2,700 DC fast charging connectors, powered by 100% renewable energy, over the next five years. This investment aims to expand fast-charging infrastructure, particularly in urban and suburban areas, supporting GM's goal to introduce several new EVs and sell a million EVs by 2025. The collaboration will increase access for those in multi-unit dwellings or without home charging, with new stations capable of charging multiple vehicles simultaneously at high power.

title: Electric-SUV Maker Li Auto Has Strong First Day on Nasdaq
summary: Chinese electric-car maker Li Auto Inc. successfully launched a $1.1 billion IPO in the U.S., with shares rising 43% on its Nasdaq debut, closing at $16.46. This makes Li Auto the second Chinese electric-car startup to list in the U.S., following Nio Inc., and comes amidst a competitive and rapidly changing electric vehicle market in China. The company also secured an additional $380 million in private placements to strengthen its position against rivals like Tesla.

title: Chinese automaker Li Auto surges more than 43% after Nasdaq debut
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker Li Auto surged over 43% on its Nasdaq debut after its $1.1 billion IPO, with shares priced higher than expected. The company's unique extended-range electric vehicle (EREV) technology, which allows charging with electricity or gasoline, addresses range anxiety for customers. This successful listing comes amid tightened scrutiny on U.S.-listed Chinese firms.

title: Tesla opens first Spokane service center
summary: Tesla Inc. has opened its first service center in Spokane, located in East Spokane. This new facility is part of the company's expansion, which includes adding 40 new service centers nationwide since Q2 2019 and a total of four facilities in Washington state. The company also has plans for aggressive growth of its Gigafactories worldwide.

title: Chinese EV startup Li Auto goes public in the US, raises $1.1 billion
summary: Chinese EV startup Li Auto has gone public on the Nasdaq, raising $1.1 billion in its IPO, making it the second Chinese EV company to list in the US. The company stands out by using a hybrid approach for its SUVs, combining an electric powertrain with a gasoline generator, to address China's charging infrastructure limitations and reduce costs. Despite raising significant capital, Li Auto faces various risks, including potential US regulatory changes for Chinese companies and accounting transparency concerns, as well as the unique regulatory challenges of its hybrid technology.

title: Chinese electric-car maker Li Auto prices IPO at $11.50, above range
summary: Chinese electric-car maker Li Auto Inc. priced its initial public offering at $11.50 per American depositary share, exceeding its proposed range of $8 to $10. The company sold 95 million ADS, raising $1.093 billion, with shares set to trade under the ticker "LI." Li Auto, which started volume production of its Li One SUV in November 2019 and delivered over 10,400 vehicles by June 30, aims to offer premium SUV performance and cabin space at a more affordable price point.

title: China’s electric SUV maker Li Auto raises $1.1 billion in US IPO
summary: Li Auto, a Chinese electric SUV startup, successfully raised $1.1 billion in its Nasdaq IPO despite US-China trade tensions, indicating strong investor interest in EV makers. The company, which targets China's growing middle class with its six-seat electric SUV, plans to use the funds to expand its operations and further develop its extended-range electric vehicle technology. While still in the red, Li Auto achieved a gross profit in Q1 2020 and its investors are bullish on its potential to match Tesla's success.

title: Tesla designer re-engineers the chocolate chip
summary: Remy Labesque, a senior industrial designer at Tesla, has redesigned the classic chocolate chip for artisanal Dandelion Chocolate. His new design is a square, faceted pyramid optimized for better taste and melt-in-your-mouth texture, addressing the shortcomings of the traditional teardrop shape. This innovative chip project, born out of a need to improve the Dandelion's cookie-making process, allows for a distinctive look and enhances the chocolate-tasting experience.

title: Tesla (TSLA) gets new record price target from Piper Sandler
summary: Piper Sandler raised its price target for Tesla (NASDAQ: TSLA) to a new record of $2,400 from $2,322 after the company reported its fourth consecutive profitable quarter in Q2 2020. Analyst Alexander Potter reiterated an Overweight rating, calling TSLA a "must own" stock due to its impressive performance, ability to overcome obstacles, and upcoming self-driving features. The analyst believes shareholders should not sell TSLA shares given the company's continuous developments and efforts to reach 500,000 deliveries despite challenges.

title: Tesla deal could make US blacklisted Israeli billionaire richer
authors: Franz Wild and Michael Kavanagh and Bloomberg
summary: Tesla's agreement to buy cobalt from Glencore could indirectly benefit Israeli billionaire Dan Gertler, who has been blacklisted from the US financial system since 2017. Gertler is entitled to royalties from Glencore's Congolese mines, which will supply most of Tesla's cobalt, raising ethical and potential legal concerns for the US company. This arrangement highlights the complexities of sourcing minerals from regions with human rights issues and corruption risks.

title: Tesla Chooses Site East Of Austin For New $1 Billion Factory
summary: Tesla announced it will build its new $1 billion electric vehicle factory east of Austin, Texas, on a 2,100-acre site off State Highway 130. The factory will produce Cybertrucks, semi-trucks, and Model 3 and Y vehicles for the Eastern U.S., creating at least 5,000 new jobs. The company secured property tax breaks from Travis County and Del Valle ISD, despite environmental challenges at the chosen site, which includes a cement plant and aggregate mine.

title: Pfizer Vaccine Deal, Microsoft's Strong Performance
summary: Pfizer announced a $1.95 billion deal with the U.S. government to deliver a coronavirus vaccine in 2021, causing its shares and BioNTech's shares to surge. Microsoft also reported strong fourth-quarter results, surpassing estimates with a 13% revenue increase, though net income decreased due to physical store closures. Tesla also beat Wall Street expectations for its second-quarter profits, with significant increases in cash and vehicle deliveries, and its stock continues to perform well.

title: GM backs away from hydrogen fuel-cell tech in passenger vehicles
summary: General Motors has stated it is no longer interested in selling hydrogen fuel-cell passenger cars, opting to focus on battery-electric vehicles for consumers. The company will instead develop fuel-cell technology for military and commercial applications, continuing its partnership with Honda in this area. This marks a shift from GM's earlier "two-pronged" approach for both battery-electric and fuel-cell powertrains in passenger vehicles.

title: About MSCI’s Global Innovation Indexes
summary: The article details MSCI's Global Innovation Indexes, which are thematic indices built in collaboration with ARK Invest to identify disruptive technologies. It explains MSCI's methodology for selecting constituents, focusing on revenue attribution to innovation themes and addressing the challenge of defining "pure-play" stocks in rapidly evolving sectors. The piece highlights specific innovation indices, like Genomic Innovation and Autonomous Technology, and discusses their unique stock selections compared to traditional tech indexes.

title: 12 EV Stocks & Electric Car Companies to Watch in 2023
summary: This article identifies 12 electric vehicle (EV) stocks to watch in 2023, including both established manufacturers and newer EV specialists. It discusses the growing EV market share, different types of electric vehicles, and how to trade on EV stocks. The article also touches on related investment opportunities like EV ETFs and share baskets.

title: German court rules that Tesla misled consumers on Autopilot and Full Self Driving
summary: A Munich court has ruled that Tesla misled consumers regarding the capabilities of its Autopilot and Full Self Driving (FSD) systems. Tesla Germany is now prohibited from using phrases like "full potential for autonomous driving" and "Autopilot inclusive" in its advertising. The ruling stems from a lawsuit filed by the Center for Protection Against Unfair Competition, which argued Tesla promised more than its technology could deliver.

title: An EV bubble? Startups ride Tesla hype to ‘staggering’ money
summary: Electric vehicle (EV) startups like Fisker, Karma, and Rivian are attracting significant investments, fueled by the soaring stock price of Tesla. Analysts express concern about a potential "hype cycle" given the large investments in relatively unproven companies. General Motors is also expanding its EV production, indicating a broader industry shift, while Tesla's valuation continues to defy traditional financial metrics.

title: CATL and Honda Sign Agreement to Form Comprehensive Strategic Alliance on Batteries for New Energy Vehicles
summary: CATL and Honda have signed a comprehensive strategic alliance to jointly develop, supply, and recycle batteries for new energy vehicles, with the first CATL-equipped Honda model launching in China in 2022. Honda has acquired approximately 1% of CATL shares, strengthening the partnership and securing a stable battery supply. This collaboration aims to accelerate global electrification and foster a long-term relationship between the two companies.

title: Electric-Vehicle Startup Rivian Raises $2.5 Billion in Funding Round
summary: Electric-vehicle startup Rivian has successfully closed a new $2.5 billion funding round led by T. Rowe Price and participated in by investors like Amazon, Ford, and BlackRock. This latest investment brings Rivian's total funding since 2019 to approximately $5.35 billion. Despite the significant capital raise, CEO RJ Scaringe stated the company is focused on launching its R1T pickup and R1S SUV in 2021, and has no immediate plans for an IPO.

title: Apple CEO Tim Cook No.2 on 2019 highest paid list at $133.7 million
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook ranked second on the 2019 highest-paid executive list with $133.7 million, largely due to an equity grant he received in 2011. Elon Musk topped the list with $595.3 million, primarily from a pay deal tied to Tesla's valuation. The article highlights the significant compensation packages in the tech industry compared to other sectors like finance.

title: Del Valle ISD Approves Tesla's Proposed Property Tax Break
summary: The Del Valle Independent School District board has approved a property tax abatement for Tesla, Inc., paving the way for the electric car maker to potentially build a $1 billion factory in Eastern Travis County. While the tax break could save Tesla up to $50 million over 10 years, the school district is still projected to gain $28 million in taxes during the same period. The decision was not unanimous, with some board members expressing concerns about a lack of negotiation, and Tesla has yet to confirm the acquisition of the land or its final factory location.

title: 1-seat, 3-wheel electric car now on display at Scottsdale mall, available to order
summary: ElectraMeccanica is showcasing its single-seat, three-wheel Solo electric vehicle at Scottsdale Fashion Square, with pre-orders currently being accepted. Designed for solo commuters, the vehicle offers a range of up to 100 miles and a top speed of 80 mph. The company is considering Arizona for a potential U.S. assembly plant to mitigate tariff concerns.

title: Who wears short shorts? Elon Musk pokes fun at Tesla’s naysayers
summary: Elon Musk has released limited edition "short shorts" on Tesla's website as a jab at short-sellers after Tesla surpassed Toyota as the world's most valuable carmaker. The move comes as Tesla's stock has nearly tripled this year, defying the automotive industry's downturn due to COVID-19. Tesla's strong second-quarter deliveries have also heightened expectations for its first four consecutive quarters of profit.

title: Sunrun to acquire Vivint Solar for $3.2 billion in all-stock transaction
summary: Sunrun announced its acquisition of Vivint Solar in an all-stock transaction valued at $3.2 billion, creating a combined entity with 500,000 customers and over 3 GW of solar assets. This move aims to achieve cost efficiencies and expand market reach in the residential solar sector, which currently has only 3% penetration in the U.S. The acquisition is expected to generate significant annual cost synergies and is anticipated to close in Q4 2020.

title: Certified: should you have your classic car restored by its manufacturer?
summary: This article discusses the trend of classic car manufacturers offering restoration and certification services for their vintage vehicles. It examines the benefits, such as increased market value and authenticity, as well as potential drawbacks like high costs and differing opinions from independent experts on the quality and accuracy of factory restorations. The article also touches on how manufacturers leverage these services to reinforce brand loyalty and offer "experiential luxury" to their affluent clientele.

title: Workhorse lands $70 million to ramp up production of electric last-mile delivery vehicles
summary: Workhorse Group Inc., a provider of electric vehicles for last-mile delivery, has secured $70 million in funding from a single institutional investor to ramp up production. The company plans to use these proceeds for operating working capital and general corporate purposes, aiming to meet its annual delivery target and accelerate production into 2021. This development occurs as the electric vehicle sector sees rising interest and competition, particularly for mid-sized trucks, despite challenges like costs and charging infrastructure.

title: Hyliion Electrified Powertrain Underscores Larger Transition in Industry
summary: Hyliion Inc.'s new Class 8 long-range electric powertrain, the Hypertruck Electric Range Extender (ERX), offers a 1,000-mile range using an undersized natural gas engine to charge batteries, aiming for carbon-free over-the-road transportation. This technology positions Hyliion in the "messy middle" of alternative powertrain development, with fleet demonstrations expected in 2021 and volume production in 2022. The company, set to merge with Tortoise Acquisition Corp., leverages existing natural gas infrastructure and targets a lower cost of ownership compared to other electric and hydrogen fuel cell trucks.

title: Lucid Air Achieves Industry-Best 0.21 Coefficient of Drag
summary: Lucid Motors announced that its Lucid Air luxury electric car has achieved an industry-best coefficient of drag of 0.21, setting a new benchmark for aerodynamic efficiency. This achievement, validated at Windshear's advanced wind tunnel, significantly contributes to the vehicle's over 400-mile range and performance. The company emphasized that aerodynamic efficiency is crucial for EVs, providing "smart range" independent of battery size and allowing the Lucid Air to offer superior performance and range.

title: Novonix teams with Canada university to manufacture advanced lithium-ion battery cathode material
summary: Novonix has partnered with the Obrovac Research Group at Dalhousie University, Canada, to manufacture single crystal NMC lithium-ion battery cathode material using its proprietary Dry Particle Microgranulation (DPMG) technique. This advanced material offers enhanced energy density and ultra-long life, crucial for EV and ESS applications, and potentially addresses the demand for million-mile battery life in electric vehicles. Novonix BTS exclusively owns the intellectual property rights to this new technology.

title: Can Lithium Keep Up With the EV Boom?
summary: The article discusses the surging demand for electric vehicles (EVs) and the potential for a lithium shortage due to lagging mining capacity. While battery production is scaling up rapidly, lithium miners are hesitant to increase production, creating a looming supply crunch that could impact EV adoption and prices. Solutions such as direct OEM investment in mining or vertical integration by miners are explored to secure future lithium supply.

title: The Cars.com 2020 American-Made Index: Which Cars Are Most American?
summary: The 2020 Cars.com American-Made Index (AMI) ranks 91 vehicles based on factors like final assembly location, U.S./Canadian parts content, and manufacturing employment, expanding significantly from previous years. The Ford Ranger tops the list, followed by the Jeep Cherokee and Tesla Model S, with Tesla vehicles making their first appearance in the top 10. A Cars.com survey highlights increasing consumer interest in buying American-made cars due to the COVID-19 pandemic, despite challenges in easily accessing such information.

title: Apple, Google and chorus of tech business leaders slam Trump's new visa restrictions
summary: Tech giants Apple and Google, along with other prominent business leaders, criticized the Trump administration's new restrictions on work visas, including the H-1B and L-1 visas. Critics argue that these restrictions, implemented to free up jobs for American workers, will actually hinder job creation and economic growth. CEOs like Tim Cook, Sundar Pichai, Brad Smith, Marc Benioff, and Elon Musk all expressed disappointment, highlighting the positive contributions of immigrant workers to innovation and the U.S. economy.

title: An Electric Pickup Truck Brings New Energy To Lordstown, Ohio
summary: The former General Motors plant in Lordstown, Ohio, which closed last year, is being retooled by Lordstown Motors to produce an electric pickup truck called the Endurance. This initiative represents a hopeful economic revival for the region, though the simpler design of electric vehicles means fewer jobs compared to traditional auto manufacturing. The community is cautiously optimistic that the new venture will bring much-needed employment back to the area.

title: Coronavirus was the perfect storm for tech innovation, and this fund manager made out
summary: The coronavirus pandemic created a perfect storm for tech innovation, benefiting fund managers like Cathie Wood whose strategy aligned with the crisis-driven upheaval of technology. Wood's ARK Invest bought into companies such as Tesla and 2U, which provided solutions to problems presented by the pandemic. She described the period as a "fascinating time to be an active manager."

title: As big as Apple: Tesla plant investment tabbed at $1.1 billion
summary: Financial details of Tesla Inc.'s proposed manufacturing plant in East Austin have emerged, revealing a $1.1 billion investment. This new facility will produce electric vehicles, and incentives and wages are also part of the ongoing discussions.

title: T-Mobile Welcomes Sprint to T-Mobile Tuesdays with Blockbuster Summer Lineup
summary: T-Mobile is extending its T-Mobile Tuesdays rewards program to Sprint customers starting June 23, offering a summer lineup of freebies, discounts, and prizes from brands like Burger King, Postmates, Shell, and Tesla. This move enhances the Un-carrier benefits for Sprint customers, including broader LTE access and 5G network integration. The program aims to thank customers with over $2 million in prizes and weekly offers, continuing T-Mobile's philosophy of loyalty without requiring points or increased spending.

title: VIA Motors International, Inc. and AT Motors Corporation announce Co-Development Partnership Agreement
summary: VIA Motors International, Inc. and AT Motors Corporation have announced a co-development partnership agreement to launch a line of Urban Delivery Electric Vehicles (UDEV's) for Mexico and international sale. The product line will include Class 2 to 5 trucks and vans, leveraging VIA's electric drive systems and modular skateboard architecture, with AT Motors handling assembly and sales support in Mexico. This collaboration aims to meet the growing demand for electrified commercial vehicles driven by eCommerce and last-mile delivery, addressing needs for sustainability, increased operating time, and lower cost of ownership.

title: Former Apple executive Jim Keller resigns from top chip design role at Intel
summary: Jim Keller, a prominent chip designer known for his work at Apple, Tesla, and AMD, has resigned from his role at Intel for personal reasons. His departure raises concerns among analysts about Intel's processor roadmap and vulnerability to competition, especially with Apple reportedly planning to use its own chips in Macs. Keller will serve as a consultant for Intel for six months during the transition.

title: Intel loses ‘rock star’ chip designer Jim Keller
summary: Intel Corp. has announced the departure of its celebrated chip designer, Jim Keller, who is leaving for "personal reasons" after two years with the company. Keller, known for his work at AMD, Apple, and Tesla, was instrumental in Intel's efforts to expand beyond traditional PC and server chips into new markets like AI and cloud computing. Despite his departure, Intel has already reorganized its engineering leadership and Keller will serve as a consultant for six months to ensure a smooth transition.

title: Tesla Stock Could Rally to $1,500
summary: Tesla Inc. stock is approaching its all-time high, with potential for a breakout above $1,000 and a rally targeting $1,500 despite challenges like production cuts and price reductions. The optimism stems from strong first-quarter earnings, a high order backlog, and technical indicators supporting a bullish outlook. The article suggests that the December breakout has been confirmed and the stock could trade significantly higher in the coming months.

title: San Jose-based Cisco promises $5M for charities fighting racism, discrimination
summary: Cisco Systems Inc. announced it would donate $5 million to charities combating racism and discrimination, following widespread protests over racial injustice. Other tech companies like Facebook, Intel, and Apple have also pledged similar contributions. This decision led Cisco to postpone its annual Cisco Live event, with CEO Chuck Robbins emphasizing the need for space and healing amid current societal turmoil.

title: POSCO’s New Growth Engine, Secondary Battery Materials
summary: POSCO Group is heavily investing in secondary battery materials as a new growth engine, aiming for 20% global market share and 17 trillion KRW in sales by 2030. The company is expanding its production capacity for both cathode and anode materials, securing raw materials like lithium, and collaborating with research institutions to drive innovation in the electric vehicle market.

title: Most General Motors plants to operate through summer shutdown
summary: General Motors announced that most of its U.S. plants, particularly truck and SUV facilities, will operate through the usual two-week summer shutdown period. This decision is to meet strengthening customer and dealer demand after production resumed on May 18 following a two-month COVID-19 related shutdown. The company noted that the restart of vehicle production has been safe and smooth.

title: Xpeng Secures Production License, Will Manufacture Cars At Zhaoqing Factory
summary: Xpeng Motors has secured a permanent production license from China’s Ministry of Industry and Information Technology for its wholly-owned Zhaoqing factory. This approval allows Xpeng to manufacture its own vehicles, including the upcoming P7 long-range sports sedan, at its advanced Guangdong Province facility. Previously, Xpeng relied on partnerships with other manufacturers like Haima Automobile for production.

title: Why Intel is betting its chips on microprocessor mastermind Jim Keller
summary: This article profiles Jim Keller, a legendary microprocessor designer who has worked for Apple, Tesla, and AMD, and is now tasked with revitalizing Intel's chip-design enterprise. It explores his unconventional career path, his philosophy of simplification and learning, and the significant impact his designs have had on the tech industry, including the Ryzen chips for AMD and the Autopilot chip for Tesla. The piece details how Intel is relying on Keller to overcome its recent struggles and regain its market leadership.

title: Elon Musk threatens to move Tesla out of California, then files lawsuit
summary: Elon Musk threatened to move Tesla's headquarters and operations out of California due to ongoing factory closures. He followed through on this threat by filing a lawsuit against Alameda County to reopen the Fremont plant. This action comes after Musk's public frustration with the restrictions preventing the car-making factory from operating.

title: Amid Lockdown Dispute, Musk Says He Will Move Tesla Out of California
summary: Elon Musk tweeted that Tesla would move its headquarters and future programs out of California to Texas or Nevada, citing a dispute over coronavirus lockdown measures in Alameda County. The potential move, which could take 12 to 18 months, comes as Tesla aims to ramp up production of its Model Y SUV at the Fremont plant. Musk has criticized the lockdown orders as a "serious risk" to U.S. business and "unconstitutional."
source: VOA - Voice of America English News
source_domain: VOA - Voice of America English News

title: Hertz and Avis cancel orders in setback for battered automakers
summary: Hertz and Avis, severely impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, have canceled vehicle orders with automakers, leading to a significant setback for the automotive industry. Automakers like GM and Hyundai are redirecting vehicles originally destined for rental fleets to dealers or other channels. This move highlights the dire state of the rental car business and its ripple effect on car manufacturers.

title: Musk Twitter rant tanks Tesla stock
summary: Shares of Tesla Inc. plunged more than 10 percent after CEO Elon Musk tweeted that the company's stock price was "too high imo" and declared he was selling almost all physical possessions. This incident raises questions about potential SEC scrutiny, especially given his past settlement regarding tweets about taking Tesla private. Analysts view Musk's controversial comments as a headache for investors but acknowledge his iconoclastic stance helps generate attention for Tesla.

title: Elon Musk: ‘This is fascist … this is not freedom’
summary: During Tesla Inc.'s earnings call, CEO Elon Musk unexpectedly called the coronavirus lockdowns "fascist" and demanded that people be given back their freedom, despite the company reporting a profit amid global turmoil. His comments, made during a formal investor call, marked a significant escalation from his prior social media posts and positioned him as a prominent critic of shelter-in-place orders, contrasting with the struggles of other automakers. While Tesla achieved a profit, other automakers like Ford and Volkswagen reported significant losses, and developments in the EV sector were mixed, with SK Innovation expanding battery production while GM and Ford delayed EV initiatives.

title: Elon Musk Decries ‘Fascist’ Stay-at-Home Orders During Tesla Earnings Call
summary: During a Tesla Inc. earnings call, Elon Musk criticized stay-at-home orders as "fascist," causing an outcry while Tesla reported its third consecutive quarterly profit and strong automotive gross margin. Despite the controversy, investors largely overlooked his comments, focusing on the company's financial performance and the potential for a stock option payout for Musk. The company acknowledged risks related to resuming production in the San Francisco Bay Area and postponed its Semi truck deliveries to 2021.

title: Ford’s Lincoln And Rivian Cancel Electric SUV Plans, Citing COVID-19 Impact
summary: Lincoln, Ford's luxury brand, has canceled an electric SUV it planned to develop with startup partner Rivian, citing the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. Although other collaborations between Ford and Rivian will continue, this specific project was halted due to difficulties exacerbated by the pandemic, including remote work challenges and delayed vehicle production. This decision comes as Ford invests heavily in electrification, but the future demand for electric vehicles remains uncertain given the collapse of the oil market and changes in regulatory incentives.

title: TrueCar’s ALG Forecasts New Vehicle Auto Sales for April 2020
summary: ALG, a subsidiary of TrueCar, Inc., projects a significant decline in new vehicle sales for April 2020 due to the Coronavirus pandemic, with total sales expected to drop 54% year-over-year. U.S. retail deliveries are forecasted to decrease by 49%, while fleet sales are anticipated to fall 77%. The report highlights a shift towards online car buying and provides detailed sales forecasts for 13 major manufacturers, showing substantial reductions across the board.

title: Delta Air Lines delays pension plan contribution citing COVID-19
summary: Delta Air Lines has delayed its pension plan contribution due to the impact of COVID-19. This decision highlights the financial strain the pandemic is placing on major companies. The article mentions related news concerning other pension funds and their investment activities.

title: Tesla can’t duck lawsuit over Musk’s take-private tweet
summary: A San Francisco federal judge ruled that Tesla Inc. must face an investor lawsuit regarding Elon Musk's 2018 tweet about taking the company private. The ruling allows shareholders to proceed with their claim that Musk's tweet was a deceptive statement that manipulated Tesla's stock price, potentially leading to billions in damages. This decision means Tesla will have to provide evidence, and Musk will likely undergo a deposition, increasing the plaintiffs' leverage in settlement discussions.

title: Lawsuits accuse United, Cigna of underpaying for behavioral health claims
summary: Four class-action lawsuits have been filed against United Behavioral Health and Cigna Behavioral Health, accusing them of underpaying providers for mental health services. The lawsuits allege that the insurers used a third-party vendor, Viant, to negotiate dramatically reduced reimbursements, leading to significant balance bills for patients and breach of contract for providers. Patients and providers are seeking justice in federal courts, claiming that regulators have ignored their complaints about these unethical practices.

title: Colgate-Palmolive partners with World Health Organization to make millions of soap bars
summary: Colgate-Palmolive is partnering with the World Health Organization to produce and donate 25 million soap bars to agencies in the U.S. to combat the spread of COVID-19. The company is also donating $20 million in health and hygiene products to local nonprofits and launching a matching gift campaign for its employees. This initiative is part of the #SafeHands effort, with Colgate utilizing five manufacturing plants for soap production.

title: Elon Musk criticized for donating sleep apnea ventilators
summary: Elon Musk is facing criticism for donating over 1,000 ventilators for COVID-19 relief that are reportedly non-invasive bilevel positive airway pressure (BPAP) machines, used for sleep apnea, rather than the invasive ventilators needed for intensive care units. While the FDA has issued guidance allowing BPAP machines as alternatives during the shortage, some critics question their safety and Musk's portrayal of the donation. Musk has defended his actions, stating hospitals were aware of the specifications, and is also assisting Medtronic in ventilator production.

title: Blink Charging Launches Portable Emergency EV Charger
summary: Blink Charging Co. has introduced a new mobile EV charging station designed for roadside assistance, providing up to 9.6 kW of charge. This portable unit can deliver up to 1 mile of charge per minute and is compatible with all EV models, including Teslas, offering both networked and non-networked configurations.

title: Blink Introduces Mobile Charging Station For Roadside EV Assistance
summary: Blink Charging has launched a portable EV charging solution designed for roadside assistance. The mobile charger provides 40-amp, 240-volt AC charging (up to 9.6kW) to give stranded EVs enough range to reach a charging station or their destination. This addresses range anxiety and makes EV ownership more convenient, particularly for commercial roadside service providers.

title: What Is All-Wheel Drive?
summary: This article defines all-wheel drive (AWD) as a type of four-wheel-drive system that automatically shifts power between front and rear wheels to maintain traction, suitable for lighter-duty winter driving and light off-pavement use. It clarifies that AWD systems power all four wheels at once and are typically found in cars, car-based SUVs, crossovers, and minivans, emphasizing that tire choice is as critical as the drivetrain for low-traction conditions.

title: Joe Holland – Charles River
summary: Joe Holland, Director of Facilities at Charles River's Reno, Nevada research facility, oversees critical infrastructure ensuring the building meets the rigorous demands of medical science and animal welfare. The article details his work on a $10 million vivarium expansion, a $1 million lab renovation for immunology assessments, and significant improvements in air quality control and energy efficiency. Holland's background as a U.S. Naval Academy graduate and his connection to the Reno area are also highlighted.

title: Tesla confirmed as Medtronic partner in ventilator production
summary: Tesla has been confirmed as a partner with medical equipment company Medtronic for ventilator production to address the medical supply shortage caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Medtronic CEO Omar Ishrak stated that Tesla would be manufacturing their Puritan Bennett 980 ventilator, with Tesla CEO Elon Musk confirming progress and indicating the Giga New York factory would reopen for production. Additionally, Musk had previously purchased and airshipped 1,200 FDA-approved ventilators from China to Los Angeles.

title: Leading the charge: After split from JCI, Clarios charts course in evolving industry
summary: Clarios, formerly Johnson Controls Power Solutions, is navigating the evolving automotive industry nearly a year after splitting from Johnson Controls International plc. The company, the world's largest automotive battery manufacturer, focuses on innovating lead-acid battery technologies like Absorbent Glass Mat (AGM) and enhanced flooded batteries, even as the electric vehicle market grows. Clarios also highlights the circular economy of lead-acid batteries, with 99% being recovered and recycled in the U.S.

title: Elon Musk once said starting an electric car company is 'idiocy squared' — now Tesla just hit 1 million cars
summary: Elon Musk famously called starting Tesla "idiocy squared" due to the low chances of success in the car manufacturing industry for new companies. Despite this, Tesla recently announced it had produced its 1 millionth vehicle, a significant milestone for a company that came close to bankruptcy in 2018. Musk's drive stems from a desire to achieve a sustainable energy economy and make the future inspiring, rather than solely financial gain, as he also expressed similar sentiments about founding SpaceX.

title: Freeport-McMoRan Stock’s Long List of Catalysts Boosts Its Buy Status
summary: Freeport-McMoRan (FCX) stock is presented as a strong buy due to its leverage to major trends like electric vehicles, renewable energy storage, and increased electricity usage, which drive demand for copper and cobalt. The company also has potential for a takeover or the sale of stakes in its mines, further boosting its value. These factors, combined with a low forward P/E ratio, make FCX an attractive investment.

title: Tesla Rebounds After Hitting Support, but Questions Remain
summary: Tesla shares fell but rebounded from lows near the 50-day moving average, influenced by wider market trends and a significant drop in new car registrations in China due to the nCov-19 outbreak. The National Transportation Safety Board also concluded an investigation finding Tesla partially responsible for a fatal Autopilot incident. Technical indicators suggest potential further downside, though stabilization of the virus in China could lead to temporary delays in Model 3 rollout and a return to normal operations.

title: ARK Investment Management’s Catherine Wood on why she is bullish on Tesla and bitcoin, and bearish on banks
authors: Special to The Globe and Mail
summary: Catherine Wood of ARK Investment Management discusses her firm's focus on disruptive innovation, explaining her bullish stance on Tesla and bitcoin, and her bearish outlook on traditional banks. She believes innovation platforms like AI, energy storage, robotics, genomics, and blockchain will drive significant wealth creation, while disrupting incumbent industries. Wood details specific investment theses and her firm's strategies for outperforming passive indexes.

title: Electrical tape on sign tricked a Tesla into speeding in a test
summary: Researchers from McAfee Inc. were able to trick a Tesla vehicle into accelerating by placing a strip of electrical tape over a speed limit sign, causing the car's cruise control to read 35 mph as 85 mph. This incident highlights potential vulnerabilities in machine learning systems used in automated driving, though McAfee states the immediate real-world risk is low given the current development stage of autonomous vehicles. The findings contribute to the field of adversarial machine learning, demonstrating how physical alterations can confuse computer vision systems in self-driving cars.

title: Tesla shares rise, reversing early losses following $2 billion stock offering
summary: Tesla announced a $2 billion common stock offering, with CEO Elon Musk purchasing $10 million and board member Larry Ellison buying up to $1 million, just two weeks after Musk stated the company would not raise more capital. Despite initial losses, Tesla's stock reversed and climbed 4.8% as analysts viewed the move as a strategic way to strengthen its balance sheet and fund expansion. The offering is expected to generate $2.3 billion in gross proceeds.

title: Lessons from Tesla’s Approach to Innovation
summary: This article examines Tesla's innovative approach, which often generates both strong criticism and adoration. It highlights how product launches like the Cybertruck are divisive but still attract significant preorders, demonstrating the company's unique market position. The authors, experts in strategy and innovation, analyze the factors contributing to Tesla's distinct trajectory in the industry.

title: Tesla Remotely Removed Autopilot From A User's Car Without Telling Them: Report
summary: Tesla Inc. remotely removed Autopilot features from a customer's used car without their knowledge, claiming the features had not been paid for. This incident raises concerns about automakers' ability to unilaterally alter features on vehicles they no longer own. The customer had purchased the car from a third-party dealer who had originally bought it from Tesla with the "Enhanced Autopilot" and "Full Self Driving Capability" features.

title: An A+ ETF For AV and AI Tech
summary: This article highlights the ARK Autonomous Technology & Robotics ETF (ARKQ) as a prime investment vehicle for artificial intelligence (AI) and autonomous vehicles (AV) technologies. ARKQ is noted for its significant allocation to Tesla and its strategic positioning to benefit from the growth in these disruptive technologies. The article delves into how AI, particularly machine learning and deep learning, is crucial for AV development due to the massive data processing requirements from vehicle sensors.

title: Tesla shares hit $900
summary: Tesla Inc. shares surged 15 percent to $900, more than doubling its market value since the start of the year, partly fueled by Panasonic Corp.'s announcement that its battery venture with Tesla is profitable. This rally is also attributed to short covering and growing investor confidence that Tesla can produce mass-volume electric vehicles profitably, with key Asian suppliers also seeing stock increases. The company reported strong vehicle delivery numbers and a second consecutive quarterly profit.

title: Opinion: Tesla is finally delivering on Musk’s promises, which are only getting bigger
summary: Tesla Inc. has finally delivered on CEO Elon Musk's promises in 2019, including hitting its annual deliveries forecast and reporting a second straight quarter of GAAP profitability. This success is leading to higher expectations for global expansion and the start of Model Y production. Despite a temporary factory shutdown in China due to the coronavirus, the company appears to be on a more stable financial footing after periods of struggle.

title: Tesla posts first annual profit
summary: Tesla reported its first annual profit in 2019, driven by a strong fourth quarter performance that exceeded Wall Street expectations. The company achieved a narrow $35.8 million profit for the year on an operating basis and anticipates continued growth with new factories and increased vehicle sales. This achievement validates CEO Elon Musk's strategy and marks a turning point for the company's financial stability.

title: Tesla Exceeds Expectations in Blowout Quarter
summary: Tesla Inc. reported blowout earnings for the second consecutive quarter and accelerated the Model Y crossover's introduction, leading to a significant surge in its stock price. Despite skepticism and challenges like reduced capital expenditures and potential impacts from the coronavirus, analysts note a strong "sentiment shift" towards Tesla as a profitable and investable company. The company projects delivering at least 500,000 vehicles this year, a more than 35% jump from 2019, and does not plan to raise capital.

title: Tesla has profitable fourth quarter, but loses $775M in 2019
summary: Tesla Inc. reported a profitable fourth quarter in 2019 but still ended the year with a net loss of $775 million, a 27% improvement from the previous year. The company delivered a record number of vehicles in both the fourth quarter and for the full year, meeting its guidance. Investors reacted positively to the results, driving share prices up and making Tesla the first publicly listed U.S. automaker to exceed $100 billion in market valuation.

title: Can Tesla Find New Buyers?
summary: This article discusses the challenges Tesla faces in expanding its customer base beyond its initial market in California, especially after the expiration of federal tax credits. It highlights that Tesla's current demographic consists of wealthy, young males in tech-related industries and emphasizes the need for new products and market expansion to ensure continued growth in the competitive EV market. The piece notes Tesla's recent move to gain sales rights in Michigan as a step towards broader accessibility.

title: Tesla Is The Clear Winner in the Battle With Michigan (Seyfarth's Future of Automotive Series)
summary: After three years of litigation, Tesla and the State of Michigan settled their dispute over a state law prohibiting direct vehicle sales and servicing by Tesla. Although the law remains, the settlement allows Tesla to operate in Michigan through workarounds, including a subsidiary-owned repair facility and galleries for out-of-state transactions. This outcome is considered a significant win for Tesla and sets a precedent for other manufacturers challenging traditional dealer network models.

title: Old Electric Car Batteries Are Now Powering the Grid
summary: Relectrify, an Australian company, is collaborating with American Electric Power and Nissan to repurpose old electric car batteries for industrial energy storage. Their battery management system aims to extend battery life by a third and halve system costs by efficiently utilizing individual cells. This method allows for the continued use of batteries that have diminished capacity, providing a cost-effective solution for grid storage and other applications.

title: Tesla hits $100bn market valuation in auto industry milestone
summary: Tesla Inc. reached a market valuation of over $100 billion, becoming the first publicly listed US-based automaker to do so, surpassing the combined value of Ford Motor Co and General Motors Co. This milestone is attributed to strong annual vehicle deliveries and increased production from its China factory, pushing CEO Elon Musk closer to earning the first tranche of a record-breaking pay package. Analysts link the surge to increased electric vehicle demand and robust performance, silencing skeptics.

title: Tesla finally wins the right to sell cars in Michigan
summary: Tesla has won the legal right to sell and service its cars in Michigan after years of legal battles. This settlement, announced Wednesday, will allow Tesla to operate in the home state of the US auto industry despite its unique direct-to-consumer sales model which traditionally conflicted with state dealership laws. Though Michigan buyers will still receive cars titled in other states, they will now be able to register them locally.

title: Tesla created demand for electric cars, but only for Teslas
summary: Despite a surge in new electric vehicle models hitting the market, Tesla remains the dominant player and virtually the only car company profiting from EV sales. Traditional automakers are hesitant to fully embrace EVs due to high costs, range anxiety among consumers, and the expectation that supply will outpace demand. While government mandates are driving EV adoption in other regions, the US market is slower to shift, with hybrids still preferred by many consumers over pure electrics.

title: 2025 Lucid Air Review, Pricing, and Specs
summary: The 2025 Lucid Air offers impressive range and performance, with up to 512 miles per charge and brutal acceleration, justifying its luxury price tag. The Pure model, starting at $71,400, is highlighted as a compelling option with 430 horsepower and a 420-mile range. Updates for 2025 include battery capacity adjustments for the Pure model, a heat pump for all trims, enhanced infotainment, and standard driver-assistance features, alongside a new complimentary maintenance plan.

title: PepsiCo moves to 100% renewable electricity in U.S.
summary: PepsiCo has announced that its U.S. operations will use 100% renewable electricity starting this year. This move is part of the company's broader goal to reduce its greenhouse-gas emissions by 20% by 2030, and is estimated to eliminate half a million metric tons of annual emissions. The company is achieving this through a mix of on-site renewable energy, virtual power-purchase agreements, and renewable-energy certificates.

title: The Mighty Apple, Google, Tesla, Dell and Microsoft in “the dock” - A Look At the Child Labour Lawsuit
summary: A landmark class-action lawsuit has been filed against Apple, Google, Tesla, Dell, and Microsoft, alleging their complicity in child labor practices within the cobalt mines of the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). The International Rights Advocates (IRA) are seeking injunctive relief and damages on behalf of child victims, arguing that these tech giants knowingly benefit from and aid in the exploitation of young children. The lawsuit highlights the horrific conditions faced by child miners and seeks comprehensive relief, including medical care, monitoring, and environmental cleanup, while asserting U.S. jurisdictional basis given the companies' operations and alleged willful ignorance.

title: Hesai raises $173M for autonomous vehicle LiDAR sensors
summary: Hesai Technology, a Chinese LiDAR maker, has raised a Series C round of $173 million from investors including Bosch Group and Lightspeed Venture. The company, which provides LiDAR sensors for autonomous vehicle developers, had previously raised over $150 million. Despite a recent patent infringement lawsuit from Velodyne, Hesai boasts a significant customer base among companies testing autonomous vehicles.

title: Tesla Bullishness Has Spotlight on “DRIV” ETF
summary: Investment firm Canaccord Genuity significantly raised its price target for Tesla, citing an acceleration in electric vehicle trends for 2020. This bullish outlook on Tesla highlights ETFs focused on electric vehicles like the Global X Autonomous & Electric Vehicles ETF (DRIV), which offers exposure to companies critical to the development of autonomous and electric vehicles. The article also suggests the Global X Lithium & Battery Tech ETF (LIT) as a less direct but relevant investment given Tesla's impact on lithium demand for battery production.

title: How Elon Musk Built a Tesla Factory in China in Less Than a Year
summary: Tesla Inc. has begun production in its new Shanghai factory, a significant step in Elon Musk's global expansion strategy. The factory, built in record time, delivered its first China-made Model 3 sedans and aims to rapidly increase production, with plans to localize component sourcing. This move positions Tesla to compete aggressively in China's large EV market against both local and global automakers, supported by government subsidies and tax exemptions.

title: Tesla Is Now the Most Valuable U.S. Car Maker of All Time
summary: Tesla Inc. has become the most valuable U.S. automaker ever, with its market value surpassing Ford Motor Co.'s 1999 peak. Tesla's shares surged at the start of 2020, reaching $81.39 billion by Monday and continuing to climb on Tuesday. Despite this achievement, the company's stock still lags behind international rivals like Toyota Motor and Volkswagen in overall value.

title: Tesla Delivers First Chinese-Made Model 3 to Customers
summary: Tesla delivered its first Chinese-made Model 3 sedans to customers from its new Shanghai Gigafactory, marking a significant step in its global expansion strategy. CEO Elon Musk announced plans for a design center in China to create a new model for worldwide sales. The move helps Tesla navigate the U.S.-China tariff war while facing a crowded Chinese electric vehicle market where sales are currently sagging despite government incentives.
source: VOA - Voice of America English News
source_domain: VOA - Voice of America English News

title: Deep-sea miners see Tesla growth as signal to pluck cobalt
summary: The opening of Tesla's Gigafactory in China and the ensuing rise in electric vehicle popularity are signaling to deep-sea mining companies that demand for battery metals, particularly cobalt, is set to skyrocket. Companies like DeepGreen Metals and Ocean Minerals are preparing to extract polymetallic nodules from the ocean floor, seeing this as a solution to projected cobalt shortages for EV batteries, despite environmental concerns and arguments that land-based resources are sufficient. They assert that deep-sea mining offers a cleaner alternative to traditional methods and is crucial for accelerating the transition to renewable energy.

title: Tesla’s stock spikes into record territory after deliveries defy ‘significant skepticism’
summary: Shares of Tesla Inc. surged to record highs on Friday after the electric vehicle maker reported impressive delivery numbers for 2019, which significantly exceeded Wall Street's expectations. The stock initially spiked by as much as 5.5% to an intraday high of $454.00, before settling to a 3.5% gain in afternoon trading. This performance defied earlier skepticism about the company's ability to meet its delivery targets.

title: Tesla just cut the price of Model 3 cars made in China
summary: Tesla has cut the starting price of its Shanghai-made Model 3 sedan by about 9% to 323,800 Chinese yuan ($46,400) just days after beginning deliveries. With government subsidies, the cost could drop to as low as 299,050 yuan ($42,900), representing a 16% discount off the original price. This move comes as Tesla aims for significant growth in China, the world's largest car market.

title: Electric Car Giant Tesla Will Launch Operations In Israel This Month
summary: Electric car manufacturer Tesla is entering the Israeli market in January 2020 by opening a pop-up shop in Ramat Aviv mall, Tel Aviv. The company registered its subsidiary, Tesla Motors Israel Ltd., in November 2019 and is actively seeking a country manager. Tesla's decision to launch in Israel comes amidst a cut in tax benefits for electric cars, which is expected to make their models relatively expensive in the country.

title: Tesla sent incomplete worker safety injury reports, California regulator says
summary: California's workplace-safety agency, Cal/OSHA, has found that Tesla omitted hundreds of injuries from annual summary data and failed to properly record other injuries in its logs since 2015. These findings contradict Tesla's public statements and executives' claims about improved workplace safety at its Fremont factory. The discrepancies raise concerns about the accuracy of reported injury rates and their impact on regulatory oversight.

title: Tesla delivers first cars made at China gigafactory
summary: Tesla Inc. made its first deliveries of cars built at its Shanghai Gigafactory on Monday, marking a significant milestone for the electric-car company. The initial 15 recipients of the China-made Model 3 vehicles are Tesla employees. This event follows a period where Tesla's stock reached record highs.

title: Tesla falls as Cowen sees deliveries hurt by ‘demand saturation’
summary: Tesla shares fell after Cowen analysts suggested that vehicle deliveries might miss the company's annual target due to "demand saturation" for the Model 3 in most mature markets, despite increased expectations for the Netherlands and China. Cowen also raised concerns about potential pricing and mix issues affecting Tesla's fourth-quarter margins and profitability, as well as long-term demand skepticism in China. This view contrasts with Wedbush's optimism regarding Tesla's prospects in China.

title: Tesla Set to Deliver First China-Built Car in Milestone for Musk
summary: Tesla Inc. is set to begin delivering its first China-built Model 3 sedans on December 30, marking a significant milestone for Elon Musk's company as it expands into the world's largest electric-vehicle market. The Shanghai Gigafactory, Tesla's first plant outside the U.S., has quickly moved from groundbreaking to production, with the first 15 units going to company employees. This move, coupled with tax exemptions and government subsidies for locally built cars, is crucial for Tesla's profitability and global expansion plans, though analysts note that parts are still largely imported for assembly.

title: The Car I Most Want to Drive in 2020 Isn’t a Car at All
summary: The author expresses a strong desire to drive the Tesla Cybertruck in 2020, despite official production starting in 2021, hoping for a prototype experience. The article highlights the Cybertruck's significant impact on public imagination and its potential to indicate the future direction of the electric truck market. It contrasts with the author's previous review of 2019 cars, focusing on this singular anticipated vehicle.

title: Tesla lines up $1.6bn in financing for its Shanghai Gigafactory
summary: Tesla has secured $1.6 billion in new financing from state-backed Chinese lenders for its Shanghai Gigafactory, which will double its Model 3 production capacity. This financing, offered on preferential terms, highlights China's support for Tesla amidst a challenging market for domestic EV startups.
