The plant aims to supply the massive Chinese automotive market while bypassing shipping costs and tariff uncertainties.

title: Tesla Secures $1.29 Billion Loan from Chinese Banks for Shanghai Factory
summary: Tesla Inc. has secured a secured term loan facility of up to 9 billion yuan ($1.29 billion) and an unsecured revolving loan facility of up to 2.25 billion yuan from Chinese banks. These loans are designated for its Shanghai car plant, which is crucial for increasing sales in the Chinese auto market and avoiding import tariffs. The funds will also be used to repay existing debt.
source: VOA - Voice of America English News
source_domain: VOA - Voice of America English News

title: Tesla confirms it secured $1.6 billion in financing for Gigafactory Shanghai
summary: Tesla has officially confirmed securing $1.6 billion in financing from Chinese banks for its Gigafactory Shanghai operations. This financing includes a secured term loan of up to RMB 9.0 billion and an unsecured revolving loan of up to RMB 2.25 billion, a portion of which was used to repay an existing bridge loan. The remaining funds are intended for the expansion of Gigafactory 3 and the production of more components locally, including the upcoming Model Y.

title: Exclusive: Tesla to take new $1.4 billion loan from Chinese banks for Shanghai factory - sources
summary: Tesla has secured a new 10 billion yuan ($1.4 billion), five-year loan facility from a consortium of Chinese banks for its Shanghai Gigafactory. This loan will partially roll over an existing 3.5 billion yuan debt and fund factory operations. The deal strengthens Tesla's position in the Chinese market, as the factory aims to produce at least 1,000 Model 3 cars weekly by the end of the year.

title: Tesla Shares Race Past $420 Buyout Figure
summary: Tesla Inc. shares surged past $420, a symbolic price that CEO Elon Musk once proposed for taking the company private. This rally signifies a major turnaround in investor confidence, as the stock had previously closed as low as $178.97 this year. The rise is attributed to a surprising third-quarter profit, the unveiling of the Cybertruck, and progress in Model 3 production in China.

title: Rivian Gets $1.3 Billion Investment in Electric Truck Venture (Published 2019)
summary: Rivian, an electric-vehicle start-up backed by Amazon and Ford, announced a $1.3 billion investment led by T. Rowe Price. This funding round, the largest for Rivian to date, brings its total investments for 2019 to $2.85 billion as it prepares to launch its truck and SUV and compete with Tesla. The investment highlights confidence in Rivian's strategy and products, but also its significant capital needs.

title: Bilibili looks beyond anime to mainstream entertainment
summary: Bilibili is actively expanding beyond its traditional anime, comic, and games (ACG) content to establish itself as a mainstream entertainment platform. This expansion includes securing exclusive streaming rights for a major e-sports event and planning a large-scale New Year's Eve show, aiming to reach a market capitalization of $10 billion. The company is also building its content ecosystem through initiatives like paid courses and supporting music content creators.

title: Leasing License Offers Tesla a Way Around Connecticut Law
summary: Tesla has found a way to operate in Connecticut by leasing its electric vehicles from its Milford site, circumventing state laws that bar the direct sale of manufacturer vehicles. This strategy leverages a leasing license, which Tesla is eligible for, despite continued opposition from the Connecticut Automotive Retailers Association that argues it violates state law. The move allows Tesla to showcase its vehicles and offer demonstration drives to residents considering a lease.

title: CEOs of Microsoft, Apple, Google and more urge Trump administration to stay in Paris climate deal
summary: 73 leaders from major companies like Microsoft, Apple, Google, and Tesla, alongside labor unions, signed a letter urging the Trump administration to remain in the Paris Agreement on climate change. They argue that staying in the agreement will strengthen U.S. competitiveness, create jobs, and foster innovation. This appeal comes after the Trump administration initiated withdrawal from the accord, with notable absences from the signatory list including Amazon's Jeff Bezos and Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg.

title: EV startup Lucid starts construction of Arizona plant
summary: Lucid Motors has begun construction on the first phase of its vehicle assembly plant in Casa Grande, Arizona, backed by a $1 billion investment from Saudi Arabia. This initial phase, costing over $300 million, is expected to be completed by late 2020 and will produce the Lucid Air, a Tesla Model S competitor. The company plans to invest over $700 million by the middle of the next decade for additional models, including an SUV.

title: Xpeng P7 Electric Sedan Shines At Guangzhou Motor Show
summary: Xpeng's P7 sports sedan was a highlight at the Guangzhou Motor Show, with its full interior reveal and pricing announced between RMB 270,000 – 370,000 ($38,400 - $52,600 US). The P7, Xpeng's second offering after the G3 SUV, is positioned as a competitor to the Tesla Model 3 in China, boasting advanced autonomous driving features and impressive performance figures. Customer deliveries in China are expected in Q2 2020, with over 15,000 pre-orders already received.

title: El lugar más árido del planeta está amenazado por culpa de la gran demanda de vehículos eléctricos y teléfonos inteligentes
summary: The Atacama Desert in Chile, the driest place on Earth, is facing severe threats due to the high demand for lithium used in electric vehicles and smartphones. Lithium extraction processes extensively exploit the desert's scarce water resources, causing irreparable damage to the fragile ecosystem and endangering indigenous communities and native wildlife. Despite scientific evidence and local community complaints about reduced water levels and environmental degradation, mining companies and the Chilean government have largely dismissed these concerns, prioritizing economic interests over environmental protection.

title: Kroger vs. Wegmans
summary: This article compares two different approaches to brand building by examining Kroger and Wegmans. Kroger, a larger supermarket chain, focuses on paid advertising and a new agency to control its message, while Wegmans, a smaller company, thrives on free media and viral publicity. The article explores the pros and cons of each strategy and how companies can build their brand.

title: PPG adds adhesives lab in Cleveland
summary: PPG Industries Inc. has opened a new advanced automotive adhesives and sealants laboratory in Cleveland, investing in new technologies to support automotive OEMs developing hybrid-electric, electric, and autonomous vehicles. The lab will focus on developing new chemistries for bonding diverse materials used in lightweighting, which is crucial for enhancing electric vehicle range. This strategic move aims to strengthen PPG's position in the adhesives and sealants market and facilitate career growth for its employees by exposing them to a wide range of automotive products.

title: Despite Unveiling Issues, Elon Musk Says Tesla Pickup Truck Orders Hit 200,000
summary: Tesla's Cybertruck orders reached 200,000 despite a flawed unveiling where two windows shattered. CEO Elon Musk confirmed the numbers, highlighting the company's strategy of taking fully refundable deposits for future products, even though previous unveiled vehicles like the Semi and Roadster are not yet in production. The high order numbers underscore strong demand, though Tesla had previously stopped reporting reservation figures.

title: Tesla shares motor up as Musk says Cybertruck orders hit 200,000
summary: Tesla's shares rose after CEO Elon Musk announced 200,000 pre-orders for the Cybertruck, despite a mixed reception at its launch event. The pre-order deposit was set at a low $100, which helped drive a flood of reservations. Musk has been actively promoting the Cybertruck on Twitter to boost sales.

title: Tesla’s Cybertruck looks weird, financial analysts say, but it could find fans
summary: Financial analysts are divided on Tesla's newly unveiled Cybertruck. While some bulls believe its "impressive feature" will attract a large audience despite its unusual appearance, bearish analysts are skeptical, questioning its broad appeal and even suggesting that the infamous broken windows incident was a deliberate stunt. The debate centers on who will ultimately buy the angular, stainless steel pickup truck beyond Tesla's core fanbase and whether it can compete with traditional manufacturers.

title: 2025 Tesla Cybertruck Review, Pricing, and Specs
summary: The 2025 Tesla Cybertruck is an otherworldly electric pickup known for its polarizing styling and bleeding-edge technology, offering giggle-producing acceleration and a natural driving feel despite its size. It's available in AWD (593-hp) and Beast (834-hp) models, with a claimed towing capacity of 11,000 pounds. Despite its unique look, it's described as a surprisingly nice-to-drive and reasonably practical full-size electric pickup, with a range extender option expected in mid-2025.

title: Tesla ‘cyberpunk’ electric pick-up truck has Detroit in sight
summary: Tesla is set to unveil its "cyberpunk" electric pick-up truck, aiming to challenge Detroit's automakers in the lucrative truck and SUV market. The truck is expected to combine the performance of a Porsche 911 with the functionality of a Ford F-150 and debut in late 2021 or early 2022 with a starting price under $50,000. Ford and GM are also developing their own electric trucks and SUVs to compete with Tesla and meet emissions standards.

title: SmartETFs Launch Smart Transportation & Technology ETF ‘MOTO’
summary: SmartETFs Funds has launched a new actively managed ETF, the SmartETFs Smart Transportation & Technology ETF (MOTO), which invests in companies benefiting from the transportation revolution, including electric and autonomous vehicles. The ETF is fully transparent, invests globally in approximately 35 equally weighted positions, and aims for long-term capital appreciation. CEO Jim Atkinson emphasizes that active management is crucial to adapt to the rapidly changing technology landscape, acknowledging the difficulty in predicting long-term winners in this competitive sector.

title: An ETF to Consider as Alphabet Shuts Down Self-Driving Car Project
summary: Alphabet's Waymo is relocating its Austin self-driving car operations to Detroit and Phoenix due to challenges in commercializing the technology. This move comes after Morgan Stanley cut Waymo's valuation by 40%. Despite these setbacks, investors can still tap into the self-driving and electric vehicle market through the iShares Self-Driving EV and Tech ETF (NYSEArca: IDRV).

title: Nio Could Be In For More Pain As Industry Association Issues Bleak EV Sales Forecast
summary: Nio (NIO) shares dropped after the China Association of Automobile Manufacturers (CAAM) reported a significant year-over-year decline in electric vehicle sales for the fourth consecutive month in October. This bleak forecast, attributed to weaker consumer demand and reduced subsidies, suggests continued pressure on the NEV market in China, despite Nio's recent individual sales rebound.

title: GM sells its Lordstown Assembly plant to electric truck start-up
summary: General Motors has sold its Lordstown Assembly plant in Ohio to Lordstown Motors, an investment group backed by electric truck maker Workhorse Group. Lordstown Motors plans to build the Endurance electric pickup at the facility, aiming for fleet sales and using experienced workers. GM also announced plans for a battery cell plant in the area, potentially creating more jobs, while Lordstown Motors and Workhorse have an intellectual property licensing agreement for the truck.

title: Tesla Reaches Preliminary Battery-Supply Deal With CATL
summary: Tesla Inc. has reportedly reached a preliminary, non-binding agreement with CATL to supply batteries for its cars made in China starting next year. The companies are also discussing expanding their relationship globally, following a meeting between Elon Musk and CATL Chairman Zeng Yuqun in August. A final agreement is anticipated by mid-2020.

title: Tesla’s solar-roof sales will grow ‘like kelp on steroids,’ Musk vows
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk predicts explosive growth for the company's solar-roof sales, comparing it to "kelp on steroids." He announced plans to install 1,000 solar roofs per week within months, marking a significant push into the energy sector alongside Tesla's electric vehicle business. The new $35,000 solar roofs are a key part of this expansion, demonstrating Tesla's ambition to integrate sustainable energy solutions into homes.

title: Elon Musk says shifting SolarCity workers helped Tesla stay afloat
summary: Elon Musk stated that he redirected SolarCity employees to work on the Model 3 program to prevent Tesla's bankruptcy, a revelation made during a lawsuit over Tesla's 2016 acquisition of SolarCity. He admitted that hindsight suggests letting SolarCity execute independently might have been better due to the immense difficulty of the Model 3 program. The article also details the ongoing shareholder lawsuit and Musk's combative deposition regarding the SolarCity deal's alleged bailout nature.

title: Tesla Model 3 Owners Tell Us What Elon Musk Got Right and Wrong
summary: A comprehensive survey of nearly 5,000 Tesla Model 3 owners by Bloomberg reveals a significant improvement in the car's quality, with defects nearly halved. While early models faced issues like paint and misaligned panels, owner satisfaction remains high for performance and design, although some software features received criticism. The survey aims to track Tesla's manufacturing consistency as it transitions to a high-volume global producer.

title: Inside Tesla’s exclusive charging lounge
summary: Tesla has created an exclusive charging lounge in Kettleman City, California, offering a premium, members-only experience to its owners while their vehicles charge. This lounge provides amenities like high-end vending machines, coffee, and a clean, clubby atmosphere, selling customers on the Tesla brand and lifestyle. While some owners appreciate the luxury and community feel, others question the long-term necessity of such lounges as charging times become shorter.

title: Tesla confirms Model Y ahead of schedule, launch in summer 2020
summary: Tesla has officially moved up the launch of its Model Y electric crossover to summer 2020, with production potentially starting as early as next year. This acceleration is partly due to efficiencies gained from building Gigafactory Shanghai, where trial production for the Model 3 has also begun ahead of schedule. The company reported a profitable quarter, strengthened Model 3 gross margins, and plans for limited volumes of the Tesla Semi in 2020, while expecting to exceed 360,000 global deliveries in 2019.

title: Elon Musk makes good on Tesla ‘short burn of the century,’ 18 months later
summary: Tesla Inc.'s surprise quarterly profit led to a significant surge in its stock price, impacting short sellers with $1.36 billion in mark-to-market losses. This event fulfills Elon Musk's "short burn of the century" prediction from May 2018, eighteen months later than his tweet. The stock rally caused a sharp turnabout for bears who had previously seen profitable short positions against Tesla.

title: Stopping Global Warming Will Cost $50 Trillion: Morgan Stanley Report
summary: A Morgan Stanley report estimates that $50 trillion in investment will be needed over the next three decades to stop global warming and achieve net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. This monumental investment will be allocated across five key areas of zero-carbon technology: renewables, electric vehicles, carbon capture and storage, hydrogen, and biofuels. The report also highlights specific companies poised to benefit from this spending and cautions about significant global GDP loss if climate targets are not met.

title: Tesla Stock Is on Fire and Shorts Are Feeling the Heat
summary: Tesla Inc. (TSLA) shares surged over 20% after the company reported better-than-expected Q3 earnings, returned to profitability, and had positive free cash flow. This positive news created significant heat for short sellers, wiping out a large portion of their year-to-date profits, as many had been betting against the company. Although short interest has been decreasing, the rally is described more as a "lingering hug" rather than a classic short squeeze due to the gradual nature of short covering.

title: Rio to produce lithium in California, joining electric car battery race
summary: Rio Tinto Group is beginning pilot production of lithium in California, utilizing waste piles from a 90-year-old mining site in Boron to produce lithium carbonate for electric car batteries. This initiative positions Rio to potentially become the largest domestic supplier of battery-grade lithium in the U.S., with plans for a significant expansion if trials continue to be successful. The move highlights the company's commitment to the electric vehicle battery market, despite competitors focusing on other commodities and a recent dip in lithium prices.

title: Brand Breakdown 002 TESLA
Hydrogen power: Toyota takes on Tesla with alternative fuel
summary: Toyota has unveiled a redesigned hydrogen-power fuel cell car, the Mirai, aiming to revive demand for the technology and compete with battery-powered electric vehicles from companies like Tesla. Despite the environmental benefits of fuel cells, their market adoption has been hindered by a lack of refueling stations and safety concerns. Toyota hopes its new "fun to drive" model, with improved range and lower production costs, will attract buyers, though it faces an uphill battle against the booming electric car market.

title: Tesla Needs Its Battery Maker. A Culture Clash Threatens Their Relationship.
Four Emerging Transportation Trends that Could Change the Future of Shipping
summary: This article explores four emerging transportation trends—Hyperloop, Uber Freight, Autonomous Vehicles, and Precision Scheduled Railroading—and their potential impacts on freight shipping. It discusses how each technology or operational change could transform the industry, addressing challenges like driver shortages and efficiency while also acknowledging their current limitations and future possibilities. The piece suggests that while some advancements are still nascent, others like modernized rail systems already offer reliable and evolving shipping solutions.

title: Lithium at two-year low hobbles US bid to loosen China’s grip on market
summary: Low lithium prices, currently at a two-year low, are hindering efforts by US miners to establish a domestic lithium supply chain and challenge China's dominance in the market. While financing new mines is challenging due to falling prices and stricter regulations, analysts predict a significant increase in lithium demand by 2023, potentially leading to a market deficit that major producers alone cannot fulfill. Companies like Piedmont Lithium and Standard Lithium are pursuing new technologies and projects in the US, but face hurdles in securing funding and approvals to meet future battery manufacturing needs.

title: Sigma Lithium Announces a Positive Feasibility Study with
summary: Sigma Lithium announced positive results for its Feasibility Study on the Xuxa deposit, projecting a life-of-mine net revenue of US$1.4 billion and an EBITDA of US$690 million. The study highlights an after-tax NPV of US$249 million and low operating costs of US$238 per tonne for battery-grade lithium concentrate, positioning the Project as economically compelling. The company plans to commence detailed engineering soon, with construction targeting March 2020, aiming for full operational status as a sustainable lithium producer by 2021.

title: China’s Tesla Rival Just Had a Nightmare Week. It May Get Worse
summary: NIO Inc. investors are facing more bad news as Sanford C. Bernstein slashed its price target for the Chinese electric-vehicle maker to 90 cents from $1.70, the first to go below $1. The company has lost over 70% of its market capitalization since its IPO a year ago, with shares falling as much as 13% on Monday after a 42% slide last week. The new price target is almost 50% below its current price.

title: Tesla, Elon Musk found to have engaged in unfair labor practices with rules and tweet
summary: A judge has ruled that Tesla Inc. and CEO Elon Musk engaged in unfair labor practices by attempting to impede union organizing efforts at its Fremont, California, factory. The ruling specifies that Tesla established rules against labor law, unfairly terminated employees, interrogated them about union activities, and suggested joining a union would be futile. Musk is required to read the findings aloud to employees at the factory.

title: General Motors vs. Tesla: Software Engineer Pay
summary: This article compares software engineer salaries at General Motors and Tesla, highlighting the significant pay gap. It discusses the competitive landscape for autonomous driving talent and notes that tech companies like Facebook, Amazon, and Google offer substantially higher compensation packages, posing a challenge for traditional auto manufacturers like GM in attracting top talent. The piece underscores the "talent war" in the autonomous vehicle space and the necessity of high compensation to secure skilled engineers.

title: Ford Reveals Electrified Vehicle Line-Up that will Surpass Conventional Petrol and Diesel by 2022
summary: Ford unveiled its most comprehensive line-up of electrified vehicles at the Frankfurt Motor Show, anticipating that electrified models will surpass conventional petrol and diesel sales in Europe by the end of 2022. The company plans to launch 17 electrified vehicles in Europe by 2024, including mild-hybrid, full-hybrid, plug-in hybrid, and all-electric options. Ford is also partnering with energy suppliers and NewMotion to provide seamless charging solutions, including home wall box installations, green energy tariffs, and access to over 118,000 public charging points across Europe.

title: ARK Industrial ETF Morphing Into Autonomous Tech, Robotics ETF
summary: The ARK Industrial Innovation ETF (ARKQ) is changing its name to "ARK Autonomous Technology & Robotics ETF" to reflect its updated investment objective. This change allows the $172 million fund to focus more on the fast-growing robotics and artificial intelligence markets, aligning with ARK Investment Management's strategy of investing in disruptive innovation. The rebranding emphasizes autonomous vehicles, robotics, 3D printing, and energy storage technologies, with a particular focus on the automated future.

title: Tesla and insurance - Everything you need to know
summary: This article details Tesla's foray into the auto insurance industry with the launch of Tesla Insurance, aiming to offer lower rates to its vehicle owners. It covers the motivations behind this move, including high traditional insurance premiums for Teslas, and the initial rollout in California. The piece also includes reactions from insurance industry experts and giants like Warren Buffett, who expressed skepticism, alongside views supporting Tesla's initiative due to its advanced safety technology.

title: Howes: Amid auto talks, Ford lays claim to being 'America's auto company'
summary: Amid upcoming UAW contract talks, Ford Motor Co. is strategically emphasizing its position as "America's auto company," contrasting with competitors like GM which build more vehicles abroad. Executive Chairman Bill Ford highlighted that Ford builds more vehicles and employs more hourly workers in the U.S. than any other automaker. This positioning is seen as an asset in negotiations and a defense against potential political criticism, as Ford leads in U.S. production and exports while minimizing non-NAFTA imports compared to GM and FCA.

title: Tesla batteries are keeping Zimbabwe’s economy running
summary: Zimbabwe is relying on Tesla's Powerwall batteries to combat severe daily power outages, which are essential for maintaining the country's economy that heavily depends on mobile and digital transactions. Mobile phone operator Econet is deploying 520 Powerwall batteries across its base stations, with plans to expand this solution to other power-starved African nations. These $6,500 lithium-ion batteries, charged by solar energy, can power a station for up to 10 hours, providing a critical alternative to scarce diesel generators.

title: Tesla just started selling auto insurance
summary: Tesla has launched its own auto insurance program in California, aiming to offer rates up to 30% lower than traditional insurers due to its extensive knowledge of its vehicles. This move could also support CEO Elon Musk's vision of a future fleet of driverless taxis, which would require commercial insurance coverage. The company sees this as a new revenue stream, despite its recent financial losses, and plans to expand nationwide, initially covering personal use with commercial policies to follow.

title: Tesla, the data company
summary: This article highlights Tesla's unique approach to leveraging artificial intelligence and machine learning, positioning it as a leading "data company" rather than just an automaker. It details how Tesla uses data from its 600,000 vehicles on the road to continuously train and improve its neural networks for autonomous driving, emphasizing its "shadow mode" testing and significant lead in accumulated real-world driving data compared to competitors. The piece also discusses the future of Mobility as a Service (MaaS) and Tesla's strategic entry into this market.

title: Philly unions worked to keep Tesla Solar out of the city. Now Walmart sues Tesla for solar panels that set its stores on fire.
summary: Walmart Inc. has sued Tesla Inc. over solar panels installed by Tesla Solar, alleging shoddy workmanship led to seven fires at Walmart stores across several states and threatened 241 other stores. This lawsuit challenges claims of renewable energy promotion by both companies and casts a negative light on Tesla, which has been facing financial difficulties and executive departures. Interestingly, Philadelphia unions had previously prevented Tesla Solar from operating in the city.

title: Teardown: Tesla Model 3 center touchscreen display (2017-19 model)
summary: This article provides a teardown analysis of the Tesla Model 3's center touchscreen display (2017-19 model), highlighting its key specifications, major components, and manufacturing cost. The display, supplied by LG Display, serves as the central control for almost all vehicle functions. The analysis identifies various semiconductor components from companies like Cypress Semiconductor, Texas Instruments, Renesas Electronics, and Rohm Co Ltd.

title: Trump attacks Ford Motor for not backing fuel economy rollback
summary: President Trump criticized Ford Motor Co. for backing a deal with California on stricter fuel economy standards, calling their executives "foolish" for not supporting his administration's plan to roll back Obama-era rules. Ford, along with Honda, BMW, and Volkswagen, reached a voluntary agreement with California, which has fuel efficiency rules stricter than Trump's proposal but looser than Obama's. Environmentalists and many states reject Trump's analysis that his proposed rule would boost vehicle safety or dramatically reduce car prices, arguing it would increase greenhouse gas emissions and oil consumption.

title: Tesla solar panels caused fires at 7 Walmart stores, retailer alleges
summary: Walmart Inc. has sued Tesla Inc., alleging that faulty solar panels installed by Tesla's energy unit caused fires at seven of its stores. Walmart claims Tesla exhibited "widespread, systemic negligence" and failed to adhere to industry standards in installation, operation, and maintenance. The retailer is seeking for Tesla to remove all panels from its stores and pay damages.

title: ElectraMeccanica hires former Tesla program manager David Neace as sales director
summary: ElectraMeccanica Vehicles Corp has appointed David Neace, a former Tesla program manager, as its new director of sales. Neace will be responsible for establishing the corporate dealership network, developing fleet sales, and increasing market presence for the company's compact electric vehicle, the SOLO. The SOLO, a three-wheel, one-seater EV costing $16,250, is set to be released in Los Angeles later this year.

title: Walmart Says Tesla Solar Panels Set Fires Atop Stores (Published 2019)
summary: Walmart is suing Tesla for breach of contract, alleging that at least seven rooftop fires at its stores between 2012 and 2018 were due to faulty solar panels installed by Tesla's solar business. The lawsuit contends "widespread, systemic negligence" in the installation and maintenance of solar systems at over 200 Walmart locations. Walmart is seeking damages and the removal of all Tesla solar power systems from its stores.

title: Is Tesla’s executive turnover really high? This analyst sets out to find the answer
summary: A Bernstein analysis suggests that Tesla Inc. experiences a significantly higher rate of executive turnover compared to similar companies. The analysis indicates that churn among top echelons at the Silicon Valley car manufacturer is "dramatically higher." This follows scrutiny on Wall Street regarding employee departures, highlighted by the recent exit of CTO J.B. Straubel.

title: ARK Invest CEO Cathie Wood: "We're Pretty Excited About Tesla"
summary: ARK Invest CEO Cathie Wood expressed strong excitement for Tesla (TSLA) despite negative market sentiment, highlighting its potential for increasing gross margins and its lead in autonomous technology. She believes the market undervalues Tesla compared to competitors like Google's Waymo and predicts that tech companies will dominate the autonomous sector. Wood also noted the market's inability to properly value Tesla, contrasting it with past tech bubbles.

title: Tesla has a huge incentive to deploy self-driving tech. But is the world ready?
summary: Tesla is aggressively pushing to deploy its Full Self-Driving (FSD) technology, driven by both Elon Musk's vision of a moral imperative and the financial incentive of unlocking hundreds of millions in deferred revenue. However, this aggressive timeline raises concerns among auto industry executives and safety advocates about premature deployment leading to accidents, damaging public trust, and confusing consumers about the technology's actual capabilities. The article questions whether Tesla's FSD is truly ready and highlights the lack of clarity surrounding its functionality and regulatory challenges.

title: Tesla scrutinized by U.S. agency over Model 3 safety claims
summary: The U.S. National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) scrutinized Tesla over Model 3 safety claims, issuing a cease-and-desist letter regarding the company's advertising statements about the vehicle's injury probability. NHTSA also subpoenaed Tesla for information on several crashes, including one involving Autopilot. The agency stated that Tesla's claims were inconsistent with its advertising guidelines and had previously raised similar issues with the Model S.

title: Newly formed Lordstown Motors Corp. moves on plans to buy GM plant
summary: Newly formed Lordstown Motors Corp., founded by Workhorse Group Inc. founder Steve Burns, is working to purchase General Motors Co.'s Lordstown plant. The company aims to raise $300 million to repurpose the plant for building electric commercial pickups and potentially U.S. Postal Service delivery trucks. The plan faces hurdles, including the need for UAW consent and skepticism about Lordstown Motors' financial capacity, given Workhorse's past sales figures.

title: Clean Energy Stocks & ETFs For Socially Conscious Investors
summary: As social responsibility gains prominence, both corporations and private investors are seeking ways to align their assets with their values, particularly in the clean energy sector. This article highlights UPS's significant commitment to renewable natural gas and suggests various clean energy ETFs like TAN, ICLN, and QCLN as smart investment choices for socially conscious investors. These ETFs offer exposure to solar, wind, and other emerging clean energy technologies.

title: EV tax credit fight sparks lobbying frenzy
summary: Automakers, electric utilities, and environmentalists are intensely lobbying to extend the federal EV tax credit through the "Driving America Forward Act," arguing it's crucial for market growth and emissions reduction. This effort faces strong opposition from the oil industry and conservative groups who view the credit as an unnecessary subsidy. The debate highlights the economic and environmental stakes involved in shaping the future of electric vehicle adoption in the US.

title: Tesla Tech Chief’s Exit Is Latest High-Profile Departure
summary: Tesla Inc. shares fell significantly after a disappointing earnings report and the announcement that longtime Chief Technology Officer JB Straubel is leaving to take on an advisory role. Investors were unnerved by a bigger-than-expected second-quarter loss, despite the company reiterating its vehicle delivery guidance. Drew Baglino is taking over Straubel's responsibilities, a move anticipated by some observers.

title: GM's driverless-taxi delay shows hype may outpace reality
summary: General Motors Co.'s autonomous-vehicle unit, GM Cruise LLC, has indefinitely delayed its plan to deploy driverless taxis in San Francisco, acknowledging that the technology isn't yet ready due to engineering and safety concerns. This delay fuels skepticism about the rapid deployment of self-driving cars and highlights the challenges in building public trust after recent accidents involving autonomous vehicles. Experts suggest that a cautious approach is necessary, as widespread deployment suitable for all conditions could still be 15 years away.

title: Lotus Evija hypercar revealed
Tesla’s latest Model 3 price cut reinforces doubts about demand for its vehicles
summary: Tesla Inc. has reduced the base price of its Model 3 sedan in the U.S. following a halving of federal tax credits, sparking concerns about sustained sales without incentive support. Analysts suggest the price cuts are to maintain demand amidst declining average selling prices and a shift towards the more affordable Model 3. Tesla has also adjusted prices for vehicles shipped to China and streamlined its global vehicle lineup.

title: This new business from Amazon represents a '$100 billion opportunity,' Morgan Stanley says
summary: Morgan Stanley estimates that Amazon's Project Kuiper, a planned network of 3,236 satellites to provide global high-speed internet, could represent a "$100 billion opportunity." This projection is based on the firm's expectation that the overall space economy will grow to over $1 trillion in the next 20 years. Project Kuiper positions Amazon to compete with companies like SpaceX in the race to build next-generation internet satellite networks, with analyst Adam Jonas highlighting Jeff Bezos's increasing financial commitment to space ventures through Blue Origin.

title: Tesla to Apple: Help us nail robocar-secrets thief
summary: Tesla is seeking Apple's help in a lawsuit against a former engineer accused of stealing confidential Autopilot files before joining Chinese startup XMotors.ai, a subsidiary of Xpeng. Both Tesla and Apple suspect their former autonomous technology engineers defected to Xpeng with proprietary information. Tesla has subpoenaed Apple, suggesting a shared interest in prosecuting alleged intellectual property theft by individuals moving to Xpeng.

title: 5 Automobile ETFs That Could Rev Up
summary: This article explores five exchange-traded funds (ETFs) that offer exposure to the automotive sector, suggesting they could perform well if the global economy remains strong. It highlights both traditional auto ETFs and those focused on related industries like palladium for catalytic converters, lithium for EV batteries, and autonomous/electric vehicle technology. The article provides details on each ETF's expense ratio, holdings, and investment thesis.

title: Former Tesla employee admits uploading Autopilot source code to his iCloud
summary: A former Tesla employee, Guangzhi Cao, admitted in a court filing to uploading Autopilot source code to his personal iCloud account in late 2018. Tesla has sued Cao for allegedly stealing trade secrets and taking them to Chinese EV startup Xiaopeng Motors (XPeng), where he is now the "head of perception." While Cao denies stealing sensitive information, he admits to creating backup copies and zip files of Autopilot source code, and deleting files and browser history before leaving Tesla.

title: EV startup Lucid Motors snaps up Tesla’s former production executive
summary: Lucid Motors, an electric vehicle startup backed by Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund, has hired Peter Hochholdinger, Tesla's former top production executive, to lead its global manufacturing operations. This strategic hire comes as Lucid prepares to produce its first electric vehicle, the Lucid Air, and as Tesla faces ongoing production challenges with its Model 3 and upcoming Model Y. Hochholdinger's extensive experience from Audi and Tesla is expected to provide crucial institutional knowledge for Lucid's manufacturing efforts.

title: Tesla Must Go ‘All Out’ to Set Deliveries Record, CEO Elon Musk Says
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk has stated that the company is on track for a record-breaking quarter in vehicle deliveries, but will need an "all out" effort in the final days of the month to achieve it. Despite concerns about demand and a slump in share prices this year, Musk expressed confidence that Tesla can hit its delivery targets. The company is pushing to get cars to the right locations and fulfill orders before the end of the quarter.

title: Tesla’s delivery numbers change multiple times between filings
summary: Tesla's vehicle production and delivery numbers are frequently updated and changed after each quarter-end, raising concerns about the accuracy of its accounting practices. This issue is compounded by high turnover within the company's accounting department. These discrepancies could indicate weaknesses in Tesla's financial reporting and disclosure controls.

title: Early on, Elon Musk gave Tesla a '10% chance of success'
summary: Elon Musk revealed that he initially gave Tesla only a "10% chance of success" in its early days, feeling pessimistic about its prospects. He recounted the widespread skepticism about electric cars and highlighted numerous close calls where the company almost failed. Despite Tesla's current challenges, Musk remains committed to its mission of sustainable transport and energy generation.

title: GM, FCA strike a deal with Tesla that consumers subsidize
summary: General Motors and Fiat Chrysler Automobiles are purchasing federal greenhouse gas credits from Tesla to meet national emissions standards, a practice that industry observers argue is ultimately subsidized by consumers buying gasoline-powered cars. Tesla has earned nearly $2 billion from selling these regulatory credits since 2010, enabling traditional automakers to comply with environmental regulations. Critics suggest this system leads to higher car prices for everyone and provides significant subsidies to Tesla buyers through tax credits and avoided sales tax.

title: Tesla Faces Skepticism About Depth of Demand
summary: Tesla is facing skepticism regarding the depth of consumer demand for its vehicles after years of focusing on production. The company's first-quarter deliveries fell 31% compared to the previous quarter, raising concerns about its sales-growth goals and the market for its high-priced sedans. This slowdown challenges Tesla's previous growth narrative.

title: Elon Musk Reveals Tesla Pickup Truck's Price: ‘Well Under $50,000’
summary: Elon Musk has revealed the anticipated price point for Tesla's upcoming electric pickup truck, stating it will be "well under $50,000," possibly starting at $49,000. This pricing strategy aims to challenge rivals like Rivian's R1T, which has a higher price tag, and target a broader demographic. Musk also detailed some expected features, including high towing capacity, long range, and advanced technology, positioning it against traditional pickups and sports cars.

title: Tesla opens orders for made-in-China Model 3, lowers price
summary: Tesla has begun taking orders for its made-in-China Model 3 vehicles, setting the base price at 328,000 yuan ($47,523), which is 49,000 yuan cheaper than imported versions. These cars will be built at Tesla's Gigafactory in Shanghai and are expected to be delivered within 6 to 10 months. The move aims to bolster Tesla's competitiveness in China, reduce delivery times, and avoid import tariffs amid trade tensions, especially after a significant drop in deliveries and share prices earlier this year.

title: Tesla's Biggest Bull Just Posted Its Valuation Model -- and There's a Huge Flaw in It
summary: This article critiques ARK Invest's valuation model for Tesla, highlighting a significant flaw in its "auto-only" bear case. While ARK's bull case relies heavily on the future of autonomous robo-taxis, the author argues that the valuation method for the automotive segment alone is based on a "ludicrous multiple" that overstates Tesla's profitability compared to peers. The piece concludes that Tesla must disrupt the mobility industry beyond just car sales for the aggressive bull case to materialize.

title: Is it time to revive the rumors that Apple will buy Tesla? Here’s why one expert thinks so
summary: Marketing professor Scott Galloway believes that Tesla Inc. is "coming undone" and will be ripe for acquisition in the near future. He specifically suggests that Apple Inc. could be the acquiring company amidst Tesla's recent struggles. This revives long-standing rumors about a potential acquisition of the electric-car maker.

title: Opinion: Fans of Tesla’s stock might find the car maker’s bonds a profitable investment
Tesla’s ‘extreme’ success in Norway becomes a double-edged sword
summary: Tesla's rapid success in Norway, a leading electric vehicle market, has created a double-edged sword as the company struggles to scale its operations to meet demand. This has led to an increase in customer complaints about service and quality issues, particularly with the new Model 3. Despite efforts to double customer service staff and open new centers, Tesla faces challenges in handling its extreme growth rate in the country.

title: General Motors designs a new “brain and nervous system” for its vehicles
summary: General Motors has developed an entirely new electronic architecture for its vehicles, designed to handle the demands of future connected, autonomous, and electric cars. This new "brain and nervous system" offers significantly higher bandwidth and processing power, enabling advanced features like ADAS, higher resolution displays, and over-the-air updates, with a strong focus on cybersecurity. The system will debut in the Cadillac CT5 and will be progressively rolled out across GM's lineup.

title: Tesla shares could drop to $10 in a worst-case scenario, Morgan Stanley says
summary: Morgan Stanley cut its worst-case forecast for Tesla stock from $97 to $10, citing concerns over the company's debt load and geopolitical exposure, particularly regarding Chinese demand. Despite this, the firm maintained its main price target of $230 and a bull-case forecast of $391, suggesting Tesla's strategic value remains high. Other firms like Baird also lowered their estimates, while T. Rowe Price significantly reduced its holdings, reflecting broader investor concerns amidst Tesla's recent poor quarterly performance and stock decline.

title: Exclusive: Tesla's solar factory is exporting most of its cells - document
summary: A report based on Reuters' review of documents reveals that the majority of solar cells produced at Tesla's New York factory are being exported rather than used in its "Solar Roof" product as intended. This highlights Tesla's struggles in the U.S. solar business following its 2016 acquisition of SolarCity. Panasonic, Tesla's partner at the factory, is increasingly selling cells to foreign buyers due to low demand from Tesla, raising questions about the viability of Tesla's solar division.

title: Cree Selected as Silicon Carbide Partner for the Volkswagen Group FAST Program
summary: Cree, Inc. has been selected as the exclusive silicon carbide partner for the Volkswagen Group’s “Future Automotive Supply Tracks” (FAST) Initiative. This partnership aims to accelerate the transition to electric vehicles by utilizing Cree's silicon carbide technology, enabling longer range, faster charging, and improved efficiency for Volkswagen's future EV models. The collaboration involves working with tier one and power module suppliers to engineer silicon carbide-based solutions.

title: |Tesla Faces 1st Trial Stemming From Allegedly Unsafe Workplace Conditions, CVN To Webcast Live
summary: The first trial against Tesla Inc. stemming from allegedly unsafe workplace conditions is set to begin in California, with Courtroom View Network webcasting live. Plaintiff Teodora Tapia, a former janitor, is seeking at least $14 million in damages after suffering severe injuries in a 2014 incident due to an unfamiliar Tesla contractor operating a vehicle. Tesla has admitted liability, leaving a jury to determine the compensation amount for Tapia's alleged permanent disability.

title: Tesla wants to cut size of board from 11 directors to 7
summary: Tesla plans to reduce the size of its board of directors from 11 to seven members, a move aimed at making the board more nimble and efficient. This decision follows increased scrutiny of the board and comes after CEO Elon Musk's tweet about taking the company private. The company is also proposing other corporate governance changes, including shortening directors' terms and dropping a supermajority voting requirement.

title: Greenlight Capital (GLRE) Q1 2019 Earnings Call Transcript
summary: Greenlight Capital Re (GLRE) reported a net income of $5.9 million for Q1 2019, contrasting with a loss in the previous year, driven by a 6.2% return on its investment portfolio. Despite growth in underwriting and investment performance, the company faced significant losses from reserve increases in its auto insurance class, primarily due to adverse events in Florida from 2015-2018. CEO Simon Burton and President David Einhorn discussed these challenges, along with market improvements in other reinsurance classes and their negative outlook on Tesla shares.

title: Tesla may be about to lose a key group of investors that have stuck with the struggling stock
summary: Tesla's recent pivot towards autonomous driving, highlighted by CEO Elon Musk's statements during an investor call, may alienate long-term growth investors who anticipated profitability from high-volume auto sales. While a recent $2.7 billion stock and bond offering provided a temporary relief rally, Barclays analyst Brian Johnson suggests the focus on autonomy pushes out the timeline for investor payoff, potentially causing "rational bulls" to reassess their investment in the struggling stock.

title: ‘I Worry Much More About Progressive’ Than Tesla, Buffett Says
summary: Warren Buffett expressed greater concern about competition from Progressive than from Tesla in the insurance business, dismissing the idea that auto companies have an inherent advantage in pricing insurance. He highlighted Progressive's superior loss ratio compared to Berkshire Hathaway's GEICO, while also praising Ajit Jain's unique talent in assessing and pricing complex, unconventional insurance contracts. Buffett reiterated the significant value of Berkshire's insurance operations, emphasizing their integration within the larger company.

title: Tesla Raises $2.35 Billion in Boosted Debt, Stock Offerings
summary: Tesla Inc. has successfully raised $2.35 billion through boosted debt and stock offerings, significantly exceeding its initial targets. This capital infusion, consisting of $750 million in common stock and $1.6 billion from convertible bonds, is expected to alleviate near-term liquidity concerns for the electric car manufacturer. The move has sparked a relief rally in Tesla's stock and bonds, leading analysts to view it as a positive step for the company's financial stability and access to capital markets.

title: Tesla raises $2.35 billion in boosted debt and stock offerings
summary: Tesla Inc. successfully raised $2.35 billion through boosted debt and stock offerings, exceeding initial plans and alleviating near-term liquidity concerns. The capital raise, which included $750 million in common stock and $1.6 billion in convertible bonds, sparked a relief rally for the company's stock and bonds. This funding will help Tesla repay debt, finance Model 3 shipments to Europe, and cover potential cash burn from softening demand, as the company invests in new vehicles and a factory in Shanghai.

title: Elon Musk owes $507 million to banks helping Tesla raise capital
summary: Elon Musk personally owes $507 million to Wall Street banks involved in Tesla's recent stock and debt sale, a figure backed by his significant stake in the electric car maker. This amount is lower than the $624 million disclosed in 2017, with Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley, and Bank of America being the primary lenders. The article highlights potential conflicts of interest for these banks and the risk of Musk being forced to sell shares if Tesla's stock price declines further.

title: Cereal Killer: Kellogg’s Must Transform Its Company to Survive—Will It Succeed?
summary: This article analyzes Kellogg's need for significant transformation to survive and thrive amidst changing consumer preferences and declining U.S. cereal demand. It discusses CEO Steve Cahillane's "Deploy for Growth" strategy, recent divestitures and acquisitions, and proposes bold recommendations including divestment of most U.S. cereal brands, capabilities-driven M&A, and radical innovation in food production and delivery, emphasizing a shift from a "Day Two" to a "Day One" company culture.

title: Tesla Delays Production of Semi Truck Until 2020
summary: Tesla has announced that production of its Semi truck will be delayed until 2020, with plans to build it at its factory near Reno, Nev. The company also reported a significant first-quarter loss of $702.1 million, more than double what analysts predicted, as sales slumped by 31%. Despite the loss, CEO Elon Musk anticipates increased demand and profit margins in the coming quarters due to updated products and pricing, and expects to return to profitability in the third quarter.

title: Tesla to Create Own Insurance Product, Says Musk
summary: During an earnings call, Elon Musk announced that Tesla is developing its own insurance product, aiming to launch it in about a month to address higher insurance rates for its vehicles. Musk stated that Tesla's direct knowledge of customer risk profiles would allow it to offer more compelling rates, potentially adjusting premiums based on driving behavior. This move follows previous attempts to partner with insurers like Liberty Mutual, and comes amidst analyst concerns about distractions from Tesla's core business and recent financial losses.

title: Tesla investors brace for grim quarterly results
summary: Tesla is expected to report a significant loss for the first quarter of 2019 after delivering fewer vehicles than anticipated. Analysts are concerned about declining Model 3 sales, difficulties in international expansion, and the impact of reduced federal tax credits, with some predicting an "outright disaster" for Q1 earnings. Despite the grim outlook, some analysts suggest a market bounce if Tesla manages to exceed lowered expectations.

title: Ford to Invest $500 Million in Rivian, a Tesla Rival (Published 2019)
summary: Ford Motor has agreed to invest $500 million in Rivian, an electric-car start-up seen as a potential rival to Tesla. This partnership aims to accelerate Ford's electric vehicle development and streamline its operations, while Rivian prepares to launch its own electric pickup truck and SUV. The investment highlights the changing dynamics in the auto industry with newcomers gaining ground through technological advancements.

title: 9 Reasons General Motors Should Dump GMC (And 12 Reasons They Shouldn't)
summary: This article examines the arguments for and against General Motors (GM) discontinuing its GMC brand. It outlines nine reasons why GM might consider shutting down GMC, such as declining sales in 2018, higher manufacturing costs for GMC trucks compared to Chevrolet counterparts, and brand overlap. Conversely, the article presents twelve reasons why GMC should remain, primarily focusing on the significant profitability of GMC trucks and their distinct market positioning.

title: Tesla holdings slashed by T. Rowe Price funds in latest cuts by investor
summary: T. Rowe Price funds significantly cut their Tesla Inc holdings in the first quarter of 2019, selling off 92 percent of their prior positions. This move by one of Tesla's largest investors follows a previous reduction in the fourth quarter of 2018. The cuts occurred during a difficult period for Tesla, marked by a drop in Model 3 deliveries and CEO Elon Musk's legal battle with the SEC.

title: EV charging stations coming to Shoppers World
summary: Shoppers World plans to install six electric vehicle charging stations, with two more near the AMC movie theater, in partnership with Volta. These stations will offer free charging subsidized by advertisements displayed on large LED screens, similar to those at Natick Mall. The project required Planning Board approval due to the advertising displays and represents an emerging use not previously covered by signage regulations.

title: David Einhorn's Greenlight says Tesla 'on the brink' of failure
summary: David Einhorn's Greenlight Capital renewed its criticism of Elon Musk and Tesla Inc., stating the electric car company appears to be "on the brink" of failure again due to issues like lack of demand, price cuts, and layoffs. Greenlight, which is short Tesla stock, noted its funds gained 11 percent in Q1 2019 despite a challenging environment for value stocks, and questioned whether Tesla would overcome its current challenges. The hedge fund highlighted Musk's unfulfilled promises regarding profitability and cash flow.

title: Opinion: Tesla and Elon Musk are creating a credibility problem
summary: MarketWatch's opinion piece argues that Tesla and Elon Musk are facing a credibility problem, evidenced by recent vehicle-delivery data. The company delivered 63,000 vehicles in the first quarter, significantly missing analyst expectations of 76,000, which caused an 8% stock drop. This comes as Musk was in federal court regarding his tweets and an agreement with U.S. regulators.

title: Tilson on Tesla: 'This is the beginning of the end'
summary: Prominent short seller Whitney Tilson, founder of Empire Financial Research, has gone bearish on Tesla stock, predicting a decline to $100 by year-end. This stance follows Tesla's Q1 sales miss, a 31% drop from the previous quarter, which Tilson views as "the beginning of the end." He cites increasing competition from European carmakers and doubts about sustained demand amidst the "wave of competition" as key reasons for his bearish outlook, despite Elon Musk's "teflon" reputation with investors.

title: Howes: Tesla turmoil, legal tangles undermine EV leadership
summary: Tesla's market position is facing significant challenges due to plummeting sales of its high-margin models and struggles to profit from the Model 3. Founder Elon Musk's ongoing legal battles with the SEC are also a major concern for investors, threatening the company's market value. Competitors from traditional automakers and Chinese EV players are rapidly emerging, further challenging Tesla's once-dominant luxury EV space.

title: 'My friends thought I was going to fail': Cathie Wood on launching Ark
summary: Cathie Wood recounts the skepticism she faced from friends when launching Ark Investment Management in 2014 after a 12-year career at AllianceBernstein. Despite the doubts, Wood was confident in her decision to build a firm focused on innovative disruptors, recognizing a significant unmet market need. Today, Ark Investment Management manages $7.4 billion in assets, establishing itself as a disruptor through its investment vehicles, holdings, and leadership.

title: Tesla starts Hardware 3 rollout: Enhanced Summon, red-light warnings
summary: Tesla has begun rolling out its new Hardware 3, bringing Enhanced Summon and red-light warnings to owners. This update also includes features like yielding to merging cars and faster Supercharging, with the company also addressing browser vulnerabilities and preparing for further Full Self-Driving capabilities.

title: G.M. Plans New Electric Vehicle Made at Chevy Bolt Plant (Published 2019)
summary: General Motors announced plans to produce a new electric vehicle at its Orion Township, Michigan plant, adding 400 jobs and investing $300 million. This move is part of the company's broader strategy to expand its electric car lineup and compete in the growing EV market, which is seeing increased competition from companies like Ford and a slowdown in sales for Tesla. The announcement comes after President Trump criticized GM for plant closures, but GM stated it has job openings and is relocating employees from idled factories.

title: Tesla sues former employees for allegedly stealing data, Autopilot source code
summary: Tesla Inc. has filed a lawsuit against a former engineer, Guangzhi Cao, for allegedly copying Autopilot source code before joining Chinese self-driving car startup Xiaopeng Motors. Separately, Tesla also sued four former employees and U.S. self-driving car startup Zoox Inc. for stealing proprietary information related to warehousing and logistics. Xiaopeng Motors has stated it's investigating the allegations against Cao, while Tesla continues to protect its intellectual property in the competitive self-driving car market.

title: Tesla sues Zoox, claims ex-workers stole trade secrets
summary: Tesla has filed lawsuits against former employees for allegedly stealing trade secrets related to its Autopilot system and sharing them with rival companies like Xpeng Motors and Zoox Inc. This comes amid a broader U.S. crackdown on Chinese corporate espionage, with Apple also having faced similar issues regarding employee theft of autonomous vehicle technology. Xpeng denies involvement in any wrongdoing and states it respects intellectual property rights, while also confirming an internal investigation into the allegations.

title: Would-Be Tesla Rival Soars After Snagging First Bull Rating
summary: ElectraMeccanica Vehicles (SOLO) saw its stock climb significantly after receiving its first analyst rating, a "speculative buy" from Benchmark analyst Bill Sutherland. The rating highlights the potential of the company's one-person electric vehicle, the SOLO, noting that 83% of cars on the highway typically have only one occupant, indicating a large addressable market. This initial bullish rating suggests the Canadian small-cap company is beginning to attract Wall Street attention as it aims to compete in the electric vehicle market.

title: The Automotive Industry: Comparing the Cultures of Ford, General Motors, Honda, Tesla and Toyota
summary: This article compares the company cultures of five major automotive manufacturers: Ford, General Motors, Honda, Tesla, and Toyota, based on employee-submitted data. It evaluates them across categories such as Company Culture, CEO satisfaction, Compensation, Perks & Benefits, Diversity, and Outlook. The analysis reveals a tie between Tesla and Ford as overall winners, highlighting their strengths in different cultural aspects.

title: Tesla Unveils Model Y Crossover, but Delivery Time Reignites Cash Concerns
summary: Tesla's unveiling of the Model Y crossover, with deliveries not expected for another 18 months, has led to renewed concerns about the company's cash position among analysts. The decision to require larger $2,500 pre-orders and the delayed delivery timeline are seen as strategies to conserve cash, potentially impacting Model 3 momentum and indicating a precarious financial situation for Tesla.

title: Tesla unveils Model Y as electric vehicle race heats up, price starts at $39,000
summary: Tesla Inc. unveiled its Model Y electric sports utility vehicle, with CEO Elon Musk announcing a long-range version priced at $47,000 with a 300-mile range and a standard version at $39,000 with a 230-mile range available in 2021. The compact SUV, built on the Model 3 platform, is positioned to compete in the fastest-growing segment in the U.S. and China, despite warnings from ratings companies like Fitch about incumbent carmakers catching up. Musk anticipates an easier production ramp for the Model Y due to shared parts with the Model 3, aiming for 1 million vehicles produced within 12 months.

title: Tesla debuts Model Y crossover
summary: Tesla has officially debuted its Model Y crossover, a vehicle seen as crucial for the company's expansion into the mainstream market and to generate revenue to manage its debts. The Model Y shares architectural elements with the Model 3, features a similar interior, and has a starting price of $47,000 for the long-range version, with a standard model expected in 2021. CEO Elon Musk emphasized that Tesla's goal extends to prompting other automakers to venture into electric vehicles.

title: Elon Musk Set to Unveil a New Tesla for the Masses—the Model Y SUV
summary: Elon Musk is preparing to unveil the Model Y compact sport-utility vehicle, aiming to expand Tesla's market beyond luxury buyers. This new all-electric compact SUV is crucial for Tesla's transition into a mass-market car company, following recent price cuts for the Model 3 sedan. The success of the Model Y is seen as critical for the automaker's future.

title: Landlords to Tesla: You’re Still on the Hook for Your Store Leases
summary: Tesla's plans to close most of its retail stores and shift to online-only sales are facing a significant challenge from landlords. Landlords show no signs of easily releasing Tesla from its existing store leases, potentially seeking court injunctions to prevent premature store closures. Many shopping center landlords haven't even been informed by Tesla about whether their specific store locations will be shut down.

title: Meet Elon Tusk: Tesla Chief Changes Twitter Display Name
summary: Elon Musk, CEO of Tesla, changed his Twitter display name to "Elon Tusk" amidst a series of late-night tweets where he also announced upcoming news from Tesla. This social media activity followed charges from the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission earlier in the week, leading Musk to accuse the regulator of failing to understand Tesla's annual reports. Tesla is also facing a $920 million convertible bond repayment due a day after his promised news release.
source: VOA - Voice of America English News
source_domain: VOA - Voice of America English News

title: SEC Says Tesla Chief Elon Musk's Tweets Violated Court Settlement
summary: The SEC has accused Tesla CEO Elon Musk of violating a court settlement by tweeting about Tesla's production numbers without prior approval. This action follows a previous settlement where Musk was stripped of his chairman title and fined for misleading investors. The SEC has asked a federal judge to hold Musk in contempt, giving him until March 11 to respond.

title: Nio CEO touts its electric cars as ‘ticket to a new lifestyle’
summary: William Li, CEO of Chinese electric-car maker Nio Inc., states that his company's vehicles are more than just luxury cars; they represent a lifestyle and a status symbol for the growing middle and upper class in China. Nio aims to be seen as a lifestyle company with its electric cars serving as a ticket to a new way of living. This perspective was shared during an interview on "60 Minutes."

title: Lucid Motors is working on an electric SUV that may debut this year
summary: Electric vehicle startup Lucid Motors is developing an SUV and plans to unveil its design as early as summer, while its first car, the Lucid Air sedan, is set for production in late 2020. The company's CTO confirmed plans for future models beyond the Air, capitalizing on its versatile platform. This development is partly driven by a $1 billion investment from Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund, though US government approval is still pending.

title: Tesla Model 3 Loses Consumer Reports Recommendation
summary: The Tesla Model 3 has lost its recommendation from Consumer Reports due to owner complaints about reliability issues, including loose-fitting exterior parts and defective glass. This caused Tesla's brand ranking to drop significantly. The magazine typically withdraws recommendations for vehicles with persistent quality concerns despite high customer satisfaction.

title: Vehicle shipping firm to operate Tesla warehouse in Kenilworth, Blau & Berg says
summary: A 14,100-square-foot property in Kenilworth, New Jersey, will serve as a warehouse and shipping point for Tesla vehicles. LNR Auto Transport will operate the space on behalf of Tesla Inc., handling servicing and transportation of Tesla vehicles from California to New Jersey for delivery to dealers and clients. The Blau & Berg Co. brokered the transaction, representing both LNR Auto Transport and Dana Development Co. LLC.

title: The CEO of General Motors makes a stop at the Toledo Transmission plant
summary: GM CEO Mary Barra visited the Toledo Transmission plant to discuss the state of business and connect with employees. She addressed employee concerns about plant closings and incidents of racist graffiti. Barra also reaffirmed GM's commitment to manufacturing in the U.S. and its zero-tolerance policy for intimidating behavior.

title: Dogs are cool, especially in Teslas with new Dog Mode
summary: Tesla has introduced a new "Dog Mode" feature for its vehicles, which keeps the air conditioner running to ensure pets are safe on hot days, even when the car is off. The car's display will inform passersby that the owner will return soon. This feature, along with a new "Sentry Mode" for security, highlights unique capabilities of electric cars.

title: WiTricity Acquires Qualcomm Halo To Accelerate EV Charging Adoption
summary: WiTricity has acquired certain technology platform and IP assets from Qualcomm Inc. and Qualcomm Technologies Inc., including over 1,500 patents related to wireless charging. This acquisition aims to streamline technology development for EV charging, making it seamless and efficient for automakers and drivers. Qualcomm Inc. will become a minority shareholder in WiTricity, and the move is expected to accelerate the commercialization and standardization of wireless EV charging globally.

title: Developers of Driverless Cars Taking A More Cautious, Low-Key Approach
summary: The driverless car industry is adopting a more cautious and low-key approach after previous bold claims and incidents like the fatal Uber crash. Companies like Aptiv, Toyota, and Waymo are emphasizing safety and more restrained deployments, focusing on specific routes and lower speeds, with full autonomy taking longer to achieve. The article highlights the increased recognition of the complexity and challenges involved in industrializing autonomous vehicle technology.

title: Ford, Volkswagen join forces on developing electric and self-driving technology
summary: Ford Motor Company and Volkswagen AG have announced a global alliance to develop and invest in electric vehicles, self-driving technology, and mobility services. This partnership, unveiled at the Detroit auto show, aims to boost competitiveness, create significant savings, and leverage the strengths of both companies without involving cross-ownership. They will co-manufacture commercial vans and medium-sized pickups beginning in 2022, with a focus on fending off tech companies in the evolving mobility landscape.
source: ABC News - Breaking News, Latest News and Videos
source_domain: ABC News - Breaking News, Latest News and Videos

title: NXP and Qualcomm fighting it out in China auto IT sector
summary: Following the failed US$44 billion merger between Qualcomm and NXP Semiconductors, the two chip giants are now competing directly in China's rapidly expanding automotive technology sector. NXP emphasizes its strong OEM relationships in China and focus on system solutions, while Qualcomm, a smartphone chip leader, introduces new chips for digital dashboards, intensifying their rivalry in the world's largest car market. The competition is highlighted by China's push for "intelligent" electric vehicles and tighter emission standards.

title: Tesla breaks ground on gigafactory in Shanghai - Xinhua | English.news.cn
summary: Tesla broke ground on its Shanghai Gigafactory, marking its first plant outside the U.S. and the first foreign carmaker to benefit from a new policy allowing wholly-owned subsidiaries in China. This factory, with an annual capacity of 500,000 electric cars and an investment of over 50 billion yuan, is expected to significantly lower Tesla's costs and prices in the world's largest electric car market. The move is also anticipated to create a "catfish effect," pushing domestic Chinese carmakers to accelerate technological upgrading.

title: Israeli company leads flying car ‘buzz’ ahead of major tech show
summary: Israeli company NFT Inc. is set to unveil its flying car prototype at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in Las Vegas. The company aims to create an affordable flying car, dubbed the "Model T of flying cars," capable of vertical takeoff/landing and auto-pilot, with a projected price tag of $50,000. While many hurdles remain, such as cost, regulation, and battery life, NFT Inc. envisions door-to-door transport with FAA approval by 2024.

title: We got a peek at the KB Home ProjeKt, the smart house of the future. Here's what we found.
summary: At CES 2019, KB Home unveiled the Builder KB Home ProjeKt, a full-scale prototype smart home showcasing over 400 integrated gadgets. This concept house features Tesla Powerwall, Google Home, movable walls, and indoor gardens, demonstrating a vision for future living focusing on health, wellness, flexibility, and sustainability. Although the initial cost is high, KB Home anticipates these advanced features will become more affordable with wider adoption.

title: Tesla names Oracle’s Ellison to board, ending US charges
summary: Tesla has appointed Oracle co-founder Larry Ellison and Walgreens Boots Alliance’s Kathleen Wilson-Thompson to its board of directors, fulfilling a requirement from a September deal with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. This move resolves federal charges against CEO Elon Musk related to his tweets about taking the company private. Analysts view Ellison's addition positively due to his experience and understanding of maverick CEOs like Musk, which could help channel Musk's energy constructively.

title: Tesla names close Musk friend Larry Ellison to board
summary: Tesla appointed Oracle co-founder Larry Ellison and Kathleen Wilson-Thompson to its board, aiming to satisfy U.S. regulators' demands for independent oversight following Elon Musk's tweets about taking the company private. Ellison, a close friend and shareholder of Musk, and Wilson-Thompson, Walgreens Boots Alliance's global head of HR, join the board amidst investor concerns about corporate governance. This move follows an SEC settlement requiring Tesla to add independent directors and control Musk's communications.

title: Saudi wealth fund invests in Tesla rival
summary: Lucid Motors, a Bay Area electric car startup, has secured over a billion dollars in investment from Saudi Arabia’s sovereign wealth fund. This funding is expected to enable Lucid to finalize the engineering of its high-end Lucid Air sedan and begin manufacturing in Arizona by 2020. The Saudi fund is also an investor in Tesla, placing it in a unique position of backing both a leading electric luxury car maker and one of its competitors.

title: More charging stations for Tesla cars likely means more customers for Bibb businesses
summary: Macon, Georgia, is seeing an increase in Tesla charging stations, which is expected to bring more customers to local businesses. While existing stations downtown are popular with both locals and travelers, new stations are being installed in north Macon to meet growing demand. Tesla declined to comment on the exact timing or location of these new stations.

title: Everything You Always Wanted to Know About Secondary Batteries
summary: This article provides an overview of secondary (rechargeable) batteries, explaining their components, advantages over primary batteries, and the significant role of lithium-ion technology. It highlights POSCO's strategic involvement in developing core materials like cathode and anode materials and its advancements in lithium extraction, aiming to become a global leader in the secondary battery market.

title: Corporate Governance Case Study: Tesla, Twitter, and the Good Weed
summary: This article examines the corporate governance implications of Elon Musk's tweets regarding taking Tesla private, focusing on Regulation FD issues. It details the SEC enforcement action against Musk and Tesla, resulting in fines, Musk's removal as chairman, and new governance requirements for the company. The authors analyze why Twitter was an unsuitable platform for such disclosures, highlighting the lack of context and clarity in Musk's statements and the ongoing fallout from the incident.
source: The Harvard Law School Forum on Corporate Governance
source_domain: The Harvard Law School Forum on Corporate Governance
